{"uri": "8201235030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:15:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:15:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:15:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/29/iran-goes-to-a-runoff-election-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hardliner-saeed-jalili/", "title": "Iran goes to a runoff election between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili - Medicine Hat News", "body": "In this photo provided by Iranian Students' News Agency, ISNA, hard-line former Iranian senior nuclear negotiator and candidate for the presidential election Saeed Jalili casts his ballot in a polling station, in Tehran, Iran, Friday, June 28, 2024. Iranians are voting in a snap election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi. (Alireza Sotakabr, ISNA via AP)DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Iran will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi, an official said Saturday, after an initial vote saw the top candidates not secure an outright win. The election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili. Mohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes. Raisi, a 63-year-old prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, died in a helicopter crash in May. THIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below. DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between little-known reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men as a runoff vote appeared likely. Iranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi who died in a helicopter crash last month. So far, no turnout figures have been offered - a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests. Voters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. After counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million. Another candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes. Iranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors. There had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said. There's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\"\u009d of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution. Raisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab. The voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip. In April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks. Meanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons. Despite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers. ___ Vahdat reported from Tehran, Iran.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201250225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:29:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:29:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:29:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/world/mid-east/iran-to-hold-runoff-vote-after-no-candidate-secures-majority", "title": "Iran to hold runoff vote after no candidate secures majority", "body": "Iran will hold a run-off vote next week after candidates Masoud Pezeshkian and Saeed Jalili failed to secure 50% of the votes, the country's interior ministry said Saturday.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nThe Interior Ministry reported that more than 19,000,000 ballots had been counted so far.\n\nComing third in the early results is the conservative parliament speaker, Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, with about 2,600,000 votes.\n\nThe fourth, Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 158,314 votes.\n\nAround 61 million Iranians were eligible to cast ballots in the elections that were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the country, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49%-- the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear program and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticized Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the country's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European capitals in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the country, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Sabah"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8201248919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:28:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:28:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:28:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2024/06/29/iran-goes-to-a-runoff-election-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hardliner-saeed-jalili/", "title": "Iran goes to a runoff election between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Iran will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi, an official said Saturday, after an initial vote saw the top candidates not secure an outright win.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nRaisi, a 63-year-old prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, died in a helicopter crash in May.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between little-known reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men as a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nIranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi who died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nSo far, no turnout figures have been offered - a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon.\n\nAfter counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million. Another candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\"\u009d of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.", "source": {"uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-06-405754628", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:06:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:06:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T12:05:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.timesofisrael.com/hardliner-moderate-to-face-off-in-2nd-ever-iranian-runoff-after-record-low-turnout/", "title": "Hardliner, moderate to face off in 2nd-ever Iranian runoff, after record low turnout", "body": "This combination of pictures created on June 29, 2024 shows (L) Iranian presidential candidate and ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili as he attends his election campaign rally at Sharif University in Tehran, June 22, 2024, and (R) lawmaker and former health minister Massoud Pezeshkian, a reformist candidate for Iranian president, at a campaign rally at Afrasiabi Stadium in Tehran, June 23, 2024. (Atta Kenare / AFP)\n\nTEHRAN (AFP) - Iran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian received over 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes; therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic Republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one, in 2005, has led to a runoff.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes. The election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic Republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran, Alireza Zakani, and Raisi's vice president, Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting voters to shun the polls en masse.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49%, which at the time was the lowest of any presidential election since the Islamic Republic was founded in 1979.\n\nDifferent camps\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear program and domestic discontent over the state of the country's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote. But opposition groups, especially in the Iranian diaspora, called for a boycott of the vote, questioning the elections' credibility.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticized Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic Republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation.\"\n\nHowever, Pezeshkian has been less welcoming of ties with Israel.\n\n\"God willing, we will try to have friendly relations with all countries except Israel,\" the reformist candidate told reporters in Tehran after casting his ballot at a local hospital.\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic Republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s. He is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": "timesofisrael.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "timesofisrael.com"}, "authors": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ebrahim_Raisi", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Ebrahim Raisi"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"uri": "8201482084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:00:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:00:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T12:00:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/06/reformist-face-ultraconservative-iran-presidency-runoff", "title": "Reformist to face ultraconservative in Iran presidency runoff", "body": "Next week's Iranian presidential election runoff pits ultraconservative Saeed Jalili (left) against reformist Masoud Pezeshkian (right) - ATTA KENARE\n\nThe sole reformist in Iran's presidential election, Masoud Pezeshkian, will face the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili in a runoff, authorities said on Saturday, following a vote marred by historically low turnout.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, secured 42.4 percent of the vote, while Jalili, a 58-year-old former nuclear negotiator, came second with 38.6 percent, according to voting figures announced by Mohsen Eslami, spokesman for Iran's elections authority.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf was next with 13.8 percent of the vote, while the only other candidate, conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, received less than one percent.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes,\" Eslami said, adding that those who finished first and second would face each other in a runoff next Friday.\n\nOnly slightly more than 40 percent of the 61 million electorate took part in Friday's first round -- a record low turnout for the Islamic republic.\n\nThe electoral authority said more than one million ballots were spoiled.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, only one has led to a runoff, which occurred in 2005.\n\nThe poll had been scheduled to take place in 2025 but was brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets candidates, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two of them -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out.\n\nBoth candidates, after the release of the final results, asked their supporters to vote for Jalili in the July 5 runoff.\n\nGhalibaf followed suit later, asking \"all revolutionary forces and supporters\" to get behind Jalili's bid for the presidency.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, the Guardian Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the election.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nJalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, the reformist newspaper Sazandegi ran the headline \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run Iran daily hailed what it called a \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-405906028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "15:51:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T15:51:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T15:40:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://english.alarabiya.net/News/middle-east/2024/06/29/who-are-masoud-pezeshkian-and-saeed-jalili-iran-s-presidential-contenders", "title": "Who are Masoud Pezeshkian and Saeed Jalili, Iran's presidential contenders?", "body": "Masoud Pezeshkian, the only reformist in Iran's presidential election, will face ultraconservative Saeed Jalili in a runoff on Friday, following a vote marked by historically low turnout.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, secured 42.4 percent of the vote, while Jalili, a 58-year-old former nuclear negotiator, came second with 38.6 percent, according to figures announced by a spokesman for Iran's election authority.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf followed with 13.8 percent of the vote, while the only other candidate, conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, received less than one percent.\n\nFor all the latest headlines follow our Google News channel online or via the app.\n\n\"None of the candidates could secure an absolute majority,\" the election authority spokesman said, noting that Pezeshkian and Jalili, who finished first and second, would compete in a runoff on July 5.\n\nJust over 40 percent of the 61 million eligible voters participated in Friday's first round - a record low turnout for the Islamic Republic.\n\nHere are some details about the two remaining candidates:\n\nMasoud Pezeshkian\n\nPezeshkian, Iran's sole reformist candidate, has risen from relative obscurity to leading the first round of the presidential election.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, garnered over 10.4 million votes in a first round on Friday that saw him facing three conservative figures, all vying to replace the late president Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash last month. Jalili secured over 9.4 million votes.\n\nAhead of the elections, Iran's main reformist coalition supported Pezeshkian, with former presidents Mohammad Khatami and moderate Hassan Rouhani endorsing his bid.\n\nPezeshkian's presidential campaign comes amid heightened regional tensions over Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip, disputes with the West over Iran's nuclear program, and domestic discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom.\n\nThe outspoken heart surgeon publicly criticized the Raisi government over the death in custody of Iranian Kurdish woman Mahsa Amini, who was arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic Republic's strict dress code for women. In a social media post, Pezeshkian called for an investigation into Amini's death following her death.\n\nIn recent campaigning, he has criticized the enforcement of mandatory hijab laws, which require women to cover their heads and necks in public since shortly after the 1979 Islamic Revolution.\n\n\"We oppose any violent and inhumane behavior towards anyone, notably our sisters and daughters, and we will not allow these actions to happen,\" he said.\n\nBorn on September 29, 1954, in Mahabad, in the northwestern province of West Azerbaijan, Pezeshkian has represented Tabriz in Iran's parliament since 2008, served as health minister in Khatami's government, and supervised medical teams during the Iran-Iraq war (1980-1988).\n\nIn 1993, Pezeshkian lost his wife and one of his children in a car accident. He never remarried and raised his remaining three children - two sons and a daughter - alone.\n\nCampaigning for Pezeshkian was Mohammad Javad Zarif, Iran's former foreign minister who secured the landmark 2015 nuclear deal with world powers. That deal fell apart three years later.\n\nPezeshkian has called for reviving the accord - which aimed to curb Tehran's nuclear activity in return for sanctions relief - to end Iran's \"isolation.\"\n\n\"If we manage to lift the sanctions, people will have an easier life while the continuation of sanctions means making people's lives miserable,\" he said during one of his televised interviews.\n\nIf elected, Pezeshkian will implement state policy under Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei, who holds ultimate authority in Iran.\n\nSaeed Jalili\n\nUltraconservative former nuclear negotiator Jalili, who will face Pezeshkian in the presidential runoff, is known for his staunch anti-Western stance.\n\nJalili, 58, aims to unify Iran's fragmented conservative factions in the upcoming runoff.\n\nJalili, who secured over 9.4 million votes, is supported by a substantial base of hardline voters who embrace the slogan \"no compromise, no surrender\" to the West.\n\nBorn on September 6, 1965, in Mashhad, Jalili comes from a devout middle-class family. Known for his soft-spoken yet rigid, religious persona, he has held several senior roles throughout his career.\n\nCurrently, Jalili is one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's top security body.\n\nJalili served in the Iran-Iraq war, where he was injured by shrapnel, leading to the amputation of his right foot. From 2007 to 2013, he led negotiations on Iran's nuclear program, maintaining an uncompromising stance.\n\nCritics accused him of ideological rhetoric during negotiations with Western governments, rather than clearly articulating Iran's position.\n\nHe has vehemently opposed the 2015 nuclear deal, arguing it violated Iran's \"red lines\" by allowing inspections of nuclear sites.\n\nJalili holds a doctorate in political science from Emam Sadegh University in Tehran, an institution established to train the cadres of the Islamic Republic.\n\nIn the early 2000s, he was part of the supreme leader's office, responsible for key strategic reports.\n\nUnder hardline president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, Jalili served as deputy foreign minister for Europe and South America.\n\nIn the 2013 presidential race, Jalili finished third, securing only 11 percent of the vote. In 2021, he withdrew his candidacy in favor of Raisi, who went on to win.\n\nPower in Iran ultimately lies with Khamenei, so the result will not herald any major policy shift on Iran's nuclear program or its support for militias across the Middle East. But the president runs the government day-to-day and can influence the tone of Iran's policy.\n\nRead more: Polls close in Iran after election to replace president killed in helicopter crash", {"uri": "8201351622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:01:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:01:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:01:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/06/reformist-ultraconservative-qualify-iran-runoff-election", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative qualify for Iran runoff election", "body": "Around 61 million Iranians were eligible to cast ballots in the election necessitated by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi - RAHEB HOMAVANDI\n\nIran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": "al-monitor.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8201899340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "19:13:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T19:13:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T19:13:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/middle-east/238869/reformist-to-face-ultra-conservative-in-iran-presidency-runoff", "title": "Reformist to face ultra conservative in Iran presidency runoff", "body": "The sole reformist in Iran's presidential election, Masoud Pezeshkian, will face the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili in a runoff, authorities said on Saturday, following a vote marred by historically low turnout.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, secured 42.4 per cent of the vote, while Jalili, a 58-year-old former nuclear negotiator, came second with 38.6 percent, according to voting figures announced by Mohsen Eslami, spokesman for Iran's elections authority.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf was next with 13.8 per cent of the vote, while the only other candidate, conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, received less than one percent.\n\n'None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes,' Eslami said, adding that those who finished first and second would face each other in a runoff next Friday.\n\nOnly slightly more than 40 per cent of the 61 million electorate took part in Friday's first round -- a record low turnout for the Islamic republic.\n\nThe electoral authority said more than one million ballots were spoiled.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, only one has led to a runoff, which occurred in 2005.\n\nThe poll had been scheduled to take place in 2025 but was brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets candidates, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two of them -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out.\n\nBoth candidates, after the release of the final results, asked their supporters to vote for Jalili in the July 5 runoff.\n\nGhalibaf followed suit later, asking 'all revolutionary forces and supporters' to get behind Jalili's bid for the presidency.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, the Guardian Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the election.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 per cent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for 'constructive relations' with Washington and European countries in order to 'get Iran out of its isolation'.\n\nJalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, the reformist newspaper Sazandegi ran the headline 'Long live hope' on its front page, while the state-run Iran daily hailed what it called a 'strong' turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8202180143", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:23:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:23:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:23:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.greaterkashmir.com/latest-news/irans-presidential-election-heads-to-a-runoff/", "title": "Iran's presidential election heads to a runoff - Greater Kashmir", "body": "New Delhi, June 29: Results from Iran's 14th presidential election indicate a runoff between reformist candidate Massoud Pezeshkian and conservative Saeed Jalili, scheduled for July 5. This announcement was made by Mohsen Eslami, spokesperson for Iran's election headquarters.\n\nVoters cast their ballots on Friday to elect a successor to President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash on May 19. The votes from 58,640 polling stations across the country, and 344 abroad, have been counted, Eslami announced on Saturday. Over 61 million Iranians were eligible to vote in this election as reported by IRNA.\n\nThe results reveal a tight race between Pezeshkian and Jalili. After counting 24,535,185 votes, Pezeshkian led with 10,415,991 votes, while Jalili garnered 9,473,298. None of the four candidates secured more than 50% of the vote, prompting the second round. This election witnessed the lowest voter turnout since the Islamic Republic was established in 1979.\n\nAnother candidate, Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, received 3,383,340 votes, while Mostafa Pourmohammadi had 206,397. Pezeshkian led with 42.5% of the votes, followed by Jalili with 38.6%, according to the state news agency IRNA.\n\nOut of 60 million eligible voters, 24 million cast their ballots, resulting in a 40% turnout, Eslami reported. Amirhossein Ghazizadeh Hashemi and Alireza Zakani had withdrawn their candidacies before the election.\n\nUnder Iranian electoral law, a runoff between the top two candidates is held on the first Friday after the result announcement if neither wins 50%+1 of the votes.\n\nOn May 19, 2024, a helicopter carrying late President Ebrahim Raisi, late Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian, and several other officials crashed while flying from Khudafarin to Tabriz, killing the president and his delegation.\n\nWHO IS MASOUD PEZESHKIAN?\n\nM\n\nasoud Pezeshkian, a former health minister under reformist president Mohammad Khatami, is a trained heart surgeon and lawmaker. He gained prominence for his opposition to the crackdown on the 2009 pro-democracy protests and violence by the morality police in 2022. After losing his wife and one of his children in a 1994 car crash, he dedicated much of his time to politics. Pezeshkian ran for president in 2013 and 2021 but was unsuccessful. The 69-year-old hails from an ethnically mixed family, with an Azeri father and a Kurdish mother.\n\nWHO IS SAEED JALILI?\n\nSaeed Jalili is an ultraconservative known for his tough stance against the West. He is a longtime top security adviser to Khamenei and a former IRGC soldier from the Iran-Iraq war. As the lead negotiator for the 2015 nuclear agreement between Iran and world powers, he was known for his firm approach.\n\nIranian media describe him as a \"firm and meticulous negotiator\" who believes Iran's economic development should not depend on foreign influence. Jalili ran for president in 2013 and again in 2021, withdrawing in favour of Raisi, who eventually won.\n\nThe elections come at a delicate time for Iran, which is embroiled in escalating tensions with Israel and Western allies, triggered by the war in Gaza and the advancement of Iran's nuclear program. The vote also took place just two months after Iran and Israel exchanged fire for the first time as the Gaza conflict widened.\n\nThe Supreme Leader Khamenei of Iran is the final decision-maker in Iran, but the elected president will represent the Islamic Republic on the global stage. The US sanctions against Iran have left the economy quite weak, and high inflation.", "source": {"uri": "greaterkashmir.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Greater Kashmir"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-405623917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:06:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:06:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:06:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/reformist-ultraconservative-qualify-iran-runoff-election-3735461", "title": "Reformist, Ultraconservative Qualify For Iran Runoff Election", "body": "Iran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": the first round, an official said yesterday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament Speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza offensive, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nYesterday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be {"uri": "8201458901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "11:38:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T11:38:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T11:38:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://arynews.tv/iran-presidential-poll-goes-runoff-none-gets-clear-majority/", "title": "Iran Presidential poll goes to runoff after none gets clear majority", "body": "TEHRAN: Iran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nDifferent camps\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's {"uri": "8201506749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:23:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:23:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T12:22:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/reformist-to-face-ultraconservative-in-iran-presidency-runoff/article_dda93654-19be-576e-b3df-911e61224db6.html", "title": "Reformist to face ultraconservative in Iran presidency runoff", "body": "Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei waves as he casts his ballot\n\nThe sole reformist in Iran's presidential election, Masoud Pezeshkian, will face the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili in a runoff, authorities said on Saturday, following a vote marred by historically low turnout.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, secured 42.4 percent of the vote, while Jalili, a 58-year-old former nuclear negotiator, came second with 38.6 percent, according to voting figures announced by Mohsen Eslami, spokesman for Iran's elections authority.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf was next with 13.8 percent of the vote, while the only other candidate, conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, received less than one percent.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes,\" Eslami said, adding that those who finished first and second would face each other in a runoff next Friday.\n\nOnly slightly more than 40 percent of the 61 million electorate took part in Friday's first round -- a record low turnout for the Islamic republic.\n\nThe electoral authority said more than one million ballots were spoiled.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, only one has led to a runoff, which occurred in 2005.\n\nThe poll had been scheduled to take place in 2025 but was brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets candidates, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two of them -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out.\n\nBoth candidates, after the release of the final results, asked their supporters to vote for Jalili in the July 5 runoff.\n\nGhalibaf followed suit later, asking \"all revolutionary forces and supporters\" to get behind Jalili's bid for the presidency.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, the Guardian Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the election.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nJalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, the reformist newspaper Sazandegi ran the headline \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run Iran daily hailed what it called a \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.\n\nrkh-pdm/dv", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, {"uri": "8200983219", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "03:48:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T03:48:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T03:47:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2024/06/28/iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hardliner-saeed-jalili/", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Early, seesawing results released Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men while a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nAfter counting over 12 million votes, Pezeshkian had 5.3 million while Jalili held 4.8 million, Iranian state television reported.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line speaker of the parliament Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.6 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 95,000 votes.\n\nIt did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet - a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Early results in Iran's presidential election put hard-liner Saeed Jalili slightly ahead Saturday, followed closely behind by reformist Masoud Pezeshkian.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put Jalili in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet - a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nWith over 10 million votes counted, Jaili had 4.26 million votes, followed by Pezeshkian with 4.24 million. Another candidate, hard-line speaker of the parliament Mohmmad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.38 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 80,000 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains in house arrest, also has refused to vote with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\"\u009d of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThis story has been corrected to say 10 million was the overall number of votes initially {"uri": "2024-06-405615665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:55:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:55:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:04:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20240629-reformist-ultraconservative-lead-iran-presidential-vote-1", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative lead Iran presidential vote", "body": "Tehran (AFP) - Iran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili are leading in snap presidential elections, according to early results on Saturday from the Interior Ministry.\n\nAccording to the latest count, Pezeshkian has won more than 8,300,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has over 7,100,000.\n\nShould the current trend continue, both candidates would head into a runoff set for July 5. The second round is required if no candidate wins 50 percent of the vote, plus one.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nThe Interior Ministry reported that more than 19,000,000 ballots had been counted so far.\n\nComing third in the early results is the conservative parliament speaker, Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, with about 2,600,000 votes.\n\nThe fourth, Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 158,314 votes.\n\nAround 61 million Iranians were eligible to cast ballots in the elections that were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent -- the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European capitals in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "RFI"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8201101098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "06:04:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T06:04:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T06:04:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/world/see-saw-vote-in-iran-narrows-presidential-race-to-two-in-neck-and-neck-count-VN6RJWTHQVOL3BQNBLGUYN6B2M/", "title": "See-saw vote in Iran narrows presidential race to two in neck-and-neck count", "body": "The two candidates in the lead are reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili.\n\nEarly results released on Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and conservative hard-line candidate Saeed Jalili.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election to replace the late hard-line president Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nAfter counting more than 14 million votes, Mr Pezeshkian had 5.9 million, while Mr Jalili held 5.5 million.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.89 million votes.\n\nShiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 111,900 votes. Voters chose between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Mr Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, and the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognised monitors.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast.\n\nIf that does not happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later.\n\nThere's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe late president Mr Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others.\n\nHe was seen as a protege of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor.\n\nStill, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988 and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory
