{"uri": "8201474687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "11:54:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T11:54:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T11:53:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/iran-to-hold-runoff-presidential-elections-reformist-pezeshkian-hard-liner-jalili-fail-to-go-head-to-head-8948964.html", "title": "Iran To Hold Runoff Presidential Elections, Reformist Pezeshkian, Hard-Liner Jalili Fail To Go Head-To-Head - News18", "body": "Hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili and reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian both failed to win more than 50% of all votes cast.\n\nIran announced Saturday it will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6% turnout.\n\nDespite the low turnout, Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi praised the public for turning out to a vote conducted without any internationally recognized observers.\n\nHe thanked the people who voted for their \"very valuable presence,\" adding that the election was held in \"complete safety\" and \"with very serious competition.\"\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, had been thought to have a wider power base, despite being plagued by corruption allegations. He is also known for launching a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999 and reportedly ordering live fire to be used against students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Though he has received notable endorsements from major reformist figures, including former Presidents (Hassan) Rouhani and Mohammad Khatami, Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before the vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, {"uri": "8201461060", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "11:40:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T11:40:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T11:40:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://newseu.cgtn.com/news/2024-06-29/Iran-heads-to-presidential-runoffs-after-low-turnout-election-1uPxOGHPZ1S/p.html", "title": "Iran heads to presidential runoffs after low turnout election", "body": "Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei casts his vote in the presidential elections. /Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader/WANA (West Asia News Agency)//Reuters\n\nIran's Masoud Pezeshkian and Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round of voting.\n\nPezeshkian, seen as more moderate in his social and foreign policies, got more than 10,400,000 votes in this week's ballot while Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator considered more conservative, has more than 9,400,000, Iran's election authority announced on Saturday.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami said.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent - the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nREAD MORE:\n\nTo Hull and back: UK's Conservatives risk losing cherished 'Red Wall'\n\nWho's set to win the UK election and what are they promising?\n\n'We will disappear': French farmers question impact of EU Green Deal\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of conservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic Republic, had originally approved six contenders. But a day ahead of the election, two candidates - the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi - dropped out of the race.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami. In recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nMeanwhile, Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance. The 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic Republic, including in the office of Supreme Leader of Iran Ali Khamenei in the early 2000s. He is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear program and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.", "source": {"uri": "newseu.cgtn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8201391917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:37:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:37:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:36:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2024/06/501_377703.html", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election with reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili after low-turnout vote", "body": "Iranian presidential candidate and reformist Massoud Pezeshkian gestures as he leaves a polling station after casting his vote in the presidential election in Tehran on June 28. AFP-Yonhap\n\nIran announced Saturday it will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50 percent of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9 percent, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8 percent turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6 percent turnout.\n\nDespite the low turnout, Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi praised the public for turning out to a vote conducted without any internationally recognized observers.\n\nHe thanked the people who voted for their \"very valuable presence,\" adding that the election was held in \"complete safety\" and \"with very serious competition.\"\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian hardline presidential candidate Saeed Jalili, center, waves after casting his vote at a polling station during the presidential election in Tehran, Iran, June 28. EPA-Yonhap\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, had been thought to have a wider power base, despiting being plagued by corruption allegations. He is also known for launching a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999 and reportedly ordering live fire to be used against students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei .\n\n\"Though he has received notable endorsements from major reformist figures, including former Presidents (Hassan) Rouhani and Mohammad Khatami, Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before the vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers. {"uri": "8201313225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:25:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:25:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:25:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13582681/Reformist-ultraconservative-qualify-Iran-runoff-election.html", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative qualify for Iran runoff election", "body": "Around 61 million Iranians were eligible to cast ballots in the election necessitated by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi\n\nIran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one led to a runoff, in 2005\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThis is the first presidential election since Iran was swept by nationwide protests over the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini after her arrest for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's dress code\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nRaisi, a 63-year-old protege of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, died in a helicopter crash in May.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-405922077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "16:14:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T16:14:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T15:26:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/reformist-ultraconservative-lead-iran-presidential-080310856.html", "title": "Reformist to face ultraconservative in Iran presidency runoff", "body": "The sole reformist in Iran's presidential election, Masoud Pezeshkian, will face the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili in a runoff, authorities said on Saturday, following a vote marred by historically low turnout.\n\nPezeshkian secured 42.4 percent of the vote, while Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, came second with 38.6 percent, according to figures from Iran's elections authority.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf was next with 13.8 percent, while the only other candidate, conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, got less than one percent.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes,\" electoral authority spokesman Mohsen Eslami said.\n\nIn his first post-election remarks, Pezeshkian thanked his supporters and urged them to vote again next Friday \"to save the country from poverty, lies, discrimination and injustice\".\n\n\"I hope your presence will be the basis of a new voice for change in attitude, behaviour, conversation and in the distribution and allocation of resources,\" he added in a video published on the website of the reformist newspaper Etemad.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called for a high turnout ahead of Friday's vote.\n\nOnly slightly more than 40 percent of the 61 million electorate took part -- a record low turnout for the Islamic republic -- and more than one million ballots were spoiled.\n\nThe poll had been scheduled to take place in 2025 but was brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\n- Conservatives consolidate -\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets candidates, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two of them -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out.\n\nAfter the final results were released, they both asked their supporters to vote for Jalili in the July 5 runoff.\n\nGhalibaf followed suit, asking \"all revolutionary forces and supporters\" to get behind Jalili's bid for the presidency.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, the Guardian Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the election.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northwestern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\n- 'Resistance' -\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nPeople, however, are not optimistic, with 32-year-old trader Sina saying, \"there will not be much change\" even if Pezeshkian is elected president.\n\n\"If he wins, he will have to work with a parliament whose head is Ghalibaf and the Supreme National Security Council whose head is Jalili,\" he added.\n\nJalili is widely recognised for his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\n\"I would like Mr. Jalili to become the president and lead Iran to progress with religious rationality based on resistance,\" said Shima, 43-year-old filmmaker in Tehran.\n\nOn Saturday, the reformist newspaper Sazandegi ran the headline \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run Iran daily hailed what it called a \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nInterior Minister Ahmad Vahidi said Friday's vote went smoothly.\n\n\"The presidential election was conducted in complete security, in perfect health, with very serious competition and with the valuable presence of people at the ballot boxes,\" he said.\n\nThe Tasnim news agency said however that militants attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in the southeastern province of Sistan-Baluchistan, {"uri": "8201379622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:25:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:25:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:24:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/reformist-ultraconservative-qualify-for-iran-runoff-election/article_dda93654-19be-576e-b3df-911e61224db6.html", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative qualify for Iran runoff election", "body": "This is the first presidential election since Iran was swept by nationwide protests over the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini after her arrest for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's dress code\n\nIran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.\n\nrkh-pdm/mz/jsa", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ramin_khanizadeh@ktbs.com", "name": "Ramin United States presidential election"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masoud_Pezeshkian", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Masoud Pezeshkian"}}, {"uri": {"eng": "Conservatism"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_republic", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Islamic republic"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran", {"uri": "8202052348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "22:49:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T22:49:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T22:49:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://jordantimes.com/news/region/reformist-face-ultraconservative-iran-presidency-run", "title": "Reformist to face ultraconservative in Iran presidency run-off", "body": "TEHRAN -- The sole reformist in Iran's presidential election, Masoud Pezeshkian, will face the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili in a run-off, authorities said on Saturday, following a vote marred by historically low turnout.\n\nPezeshkian secured 42.4 per cent of the vote, while Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, came second with 38.6 per cent, according to figures from Iran's elections authority.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf was next with 13.8 per cent, while the only other candidate, conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, got less than 1 per cent.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes,\" electoral authority spokesman Mohsen Eslami said.\n\nIn his first post-election remarks, Pezeshkian thanked his supporters and urged them to vote again next Friday \"to save the country from poverty, lies, discrimination and injustice\".\n\n\"I hope your presence will be the basis of a new voice for change in attitude, behaviour, conversation and in the distribution and allocation of resources,\" he added in a video published on the website of the reformist newspaper Etemad.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called for a high turnout ahead of Friday's vote.\n\nOnly slightly more than 40 per cent of the 61 million electorate took part -- a record low turnout for the Islamic republic -- and more than one million ballots were spoiled.\n\nThe poll had been scheduled to take place in 2025 but was brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets candidates, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two of them -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out.\n\nAfter the final results were released, they both asked their supporters to vote for Jalili in the July 5 runoff.\n\nGhalibaf followed suit, asking \"all revolutionary forces and supporters\" to get behind Jalili's bid for the presidency.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, the Guardian Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the election.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 per cent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northwestern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\n'Resistance'\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nPeople, however, are not optimistic, with 32-year-old trader Sina saying, \"there will not be much change\" even if Pezeshkian is elected president.\n\n\"If he wins, he will have to work with a parliament whose head is Ghalibaf and the Supreme National Security Council whose head is Jalili,\" he added.\n\nJalili is widely recognised for his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\n\"I would like Mr. Jalili to become the president and lead Iran to progress with religious rationality based on resistance,\" said Shima, 43-year-old filmmaker in Tehran.\n\nOn Saturday, the reformist newspaper Sazandegi ran the headline \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run Iran daily hailed what it called a \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nInterior Minister Ahmad Vahidi said Friday's vote went smoothly.\n\n\"The presidential election was conducted in complete security, in perfect health, with very serious competition and with the valuable presence of people at the ballot boxes,\" he said.\n\nThe Tasnim news agency said however that militants attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in the southeastern province of Sistan-Baluchistan, leaving two policemen dead and others wounded.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201265539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:44:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:44:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:44:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/iran-goes-to-a-runoff-election-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-saeed-jalili/articleshow/111360556.cms", "title": "Iran goes to a runoff election between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "First candidate drops out of Iran presidential election, due to take place Friday amid voter apathyIran will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi, an official said Saturday, after an initial vote saw the top candidates not secure an outright win. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. {"uri": "8202179993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:23:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:23:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:23:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/iran-president-election-result-masoud-pezeshkian-saeed-jalili-run-off-election-2560237-2024-06-30", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election after historic low turnout in presidential polls", "body": "Reformist Masoud Pezeshkian will face hardliner Saeed Jalili in runoff polls\n\nIran will hold a runoff presidential election pitting a little-known reformist against a hard-line former nuclear negotiator after results released Saturday showed the lowest-ever poll turnout in the Islamic Republic's history.\n\nMore than 60 per cent of voters cast no ballot in the race that saw reformist Masoud Pezeshkian best Saeed Jalili, who competed alongside two other hard-liners.\n\nWith Jalili now alone in facing the cardiac surgeon, Pezeshkian's campaign would need to draw voters to the July 5 runoff in an election they've otherwise not taken part in as public anger hardens following years of Iran facing economic hardships and mass protests under its Shiite theocracy.\n\n\"Let's look at it as a protest in its own right: A very widespread choice to reject what's on offer - both the candidates and the system,\" said Sanam Vakil, the director of Chatham House's Middle East and North Africa program. \"That tells us a lot about public opinion and apathy, frustration. It sort of brings it all together.\"\n\nOf the 24.5 million votes cast in Friday's election, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million, election spokesman Mohsen Eslami announced. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million, while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50 per cent of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one other runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognised monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9 per cent, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8 per cent turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6 per cent turnout.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote. Jalili is known as the \"Living Martyr\" after losing a leg in the 1980s Iran-Iraq war and is famous among Western diplomats for his haranguing lectures and hard-line stances.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard and head of Iran's police, had been thought to have a wider power base, despite being plagued by corruption allegations and his role in past violent crackdowns.\n\nHe quickly endorsed Jalili in conceding the result and criticised Pezeshkian for allying himself with President Hassan Rouhani and his former foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif. The two reached Iran's 2015 nuclear deal with world powers, which later collapsed after then-President Donald Trump unilaterally withdrew from the accord.\n\n\"The road is not over yet, and despite the fact that I respect Mr. Dr. Pezeshkian personally, ... I ask all the revolutionary forces and my supporters to help stop the wave that is causing an important part of our economic and political problems today,\" Qalibaf said in a statement.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before Friday's vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nFriday's vote saw only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nThe runoff election comes as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip. In April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel. Militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nVakil said that \"it's going to rest on if the general public, that 60 per cent who stayed home, are going to come out and protect themselves from those hard-line views\" Jalili holds. \"That's what next Friday is going to be about.\"", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masoud_Pezeshkian", "type": "person", {"uri": "2024-06-405758709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:10:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:10:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:29:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.aol.com/iran-presidential-election-heads-runoff-082855215.html", "title": "Iran's presidential election heads to a runoff after reformist wins most votes", "body": "Iran's presidential election heads to a runoff after reformist wins most votes\n\nNadeen Ebrahim, Frederik Pleitgen, Joseph Ataman and Mostafa Salem, CNN\n\nJune 29, 2024 at 12:29 PM\n\nA reformist candidate won the most votes in the first round of Iran's presidential election and will face a conservative hardliner in a run-off next week.\n\nNone of the four candidates secured more than 50% of the vote in Friday's election, prompting a second round on July 5. The election saw the lowest voter turnout for a presidential election since the Islamic Republic was established in 1979.\n\nReformist lawmaker Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, who received the most votes, will face off in the runoff, according to Mohsen Eslami, the spokesperson for the election committee.\n\nPezeshkian led with 42.5% of the votes, followed by Jalili with 38.6%, according to the state news agency IRNA. Out of 60 million eligible voters, 24 million cast their ballots, resulting in a 40% turnout, Eslami said.\n\nThe results will be reviewed by the Guardian Council, the powerful 12-member body tasked with overseeing elections and legislation, before the two candidates start campaigning again.\n\nThe snap election was held after Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi died in a helicopter crash on May 19 in the country's remote northwest, along with Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian and other officials.\n\nTwo conservatives dropped out of the race just a day before the elections to help the hardline candidates consolidate the conservative vote.\n\nPezeshkian was the only reformist candidate after dozens of other contenders were barred from running by the Guardian Council.\n\nThe Iranian electoral process has been marred by voter apathy of late, causing embarrassment to an establishment that has relied on high voter turnout to bolster its democratic credentials and popular legitimacy.\n\nNationwide discontent was evident in low voter turnout in both parliamentary and presidential elections in recent years. While Iran has boasted exceptionally high voter participation, its last legislative election in March recorded the lowest turnout since in 1979, despite government efforts to rally voters ahead of the ballot.\n\nIran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei urged Iranians to head to the polls and vote after he cast his ballot in the election on Friday morning.\n\n\"People's participation is part of the essence of the state and continuation of the existence of the Islamic Republic and its status in the world is tied to people's participation\", he said.\n\nSina Toossi, an Iran analyst and senior fellow at the Center for International Policy in Washington, DC, said Pezeshkian may have been allowed to run in the elections in an attempt to boost voter turnout.\n\n\"This move could be seen as a strategy to create a more dynamic and engaging election process, thereby encouraging greater public participation,\" he told CNN.\n\nWho is Masoud Pezeshkian?\n\nThe two candidates set to compete in the next round of elections represent opposite sides of Iran's political spectrum, and both have run for presidential elections unsuccessfully in the past.\n\nA health minister under reformist president Mohammad Khatami, Pezeshkian is a trained heart surgeon and lawmaker.\n\nHe gained prominence for his stance against the crackdown on the 2009 pro-democracy protests and violence perpetrated by the morality police in 2022 following the death of a young woman in police custody after she was detained for not adhering to the Islamic Republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nDuring the 2022 protests, Pezeshkian said in an interview with Iran's IRINN TV: \"It is our fault. We want to implement religious faith through the use of force. This is scientifically impossible.\"\n\nAfter losing his wife and one of his children in a 1994 car crash, he devoted much of his time to politics. Pezeshkian ran for president in the 2013 and 2021 elections, but failed to make headway.\n\nThe 69-year-old hails from an ethnically mixed family - his father is Azeri and his mother is Kurdish. Persian isn't his mother tongue. That has burnished his image for Iran's minorities but left him open to xenophobic attacks from some opponents.\n\nA more moderate face in the presidency could make it easier for Western states to have conversations with Iran, particularly on the nuclear issue, regional issues and trade, Vali Nasr, a Middle East academic and former adviser to the US State Department, told CNN.\n\nAhead of Friday's vote, however, Khamenei condemned those seeking improved relations with the West. Pezeshkian has publicly stated that he would defer to Khamenei on matters of foreign policy.\n\nWho is Saeed Jalili?\n\nJalili is an ultraconservative hawk known for his uncompromising dealings with the West. He is a longtime top security adviser to Khamenei and a former soldier with the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) during the decade-long Iran-Iraq war.\n\nAs lead negotiator of the landmark 2015 nuclear agreement between Iran and world powers, he spearheaded Tehran's efforts to win sanctions relief in exchange for controls on its nuclear program. He emerged as a hard-headed opponent, often lecturing US officials on Iran's rights during negotiations in Geneva.\n\nIranian media outlets describe him as \"a firm and meticulous negotiator who did not make concessions\" during nuclear negotiations, believing Iran's economic development should not depend on \"foreign will,\" lines echoed by the Supreme Leader ahead of the Friday vote.\n\nJalili unsuccessfully ran for the 2013 presidential election. He ran again in 2021, but withdrew in favor of Raisi, who eventually won.\n\nNasr, the Middle East academic, says that with Friday's election, the clerical establishment in Iran may have been rethinking what the last presidential election produced. Under Raisi, he says, \"the entire system became uniformly hardline, conservative.\"\n\nArash Azizi, an Iranian writer and fellow at the Center for Middle East and Global Order (CMEG), said that \"a victory by the fundamentalist Jalili\" would complicate efforts to restart negotiations with the West.\n\nEscalating tensions\n\nThe elections came at a delicate time for the Islamic Republic. The country is embroiled in escalating tensions with Israel and its Western allies, triggered by the war in Gaza and the advancement of Iran's nuclear program.\n\nThe vote also takes place just two months after Iran and Israel exchanged fire for the first time as the Gaza conflict widened. Israel is now preparing for a potential second front with Hezbollah, Iran's primary regional proxy, in Lebanon.\n\nAzizi said Iran's shadow war with Israel \"will go on regardless of who wins\" as the most important decisions in that regard are taken by Khamenei and security bodies, not the president.\n\nThe country's Supreme Leader is the final arbiter for most decisions in Iran, but the elected president will be the face of the Islamic Republic abroad.\n\nIran's fight with the US has left the economy in tatters, crippled by years of American sanctions, a weakening local currency and high inflation.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nadeen_ebrahim@aol.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-06-405784301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:47:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:47:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T07:27:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jun/29/iran-to-hold-runoff-election-with-reformist-pezesh/", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election with reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili after low-turnout vote", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Iran will hold a runoff presidential election pitting a little-known reformist against a hard-line former nuclear negotiator after results released Saturday showed the lowest-ever poll turnout in the Islamic Republic's history.\n\nMore than 60% of voters cast no ballot in the race that saw reformist Masoud Pezeshkian best Saeed Jalili, who competed alongside two other hard-liners.\n\nWith Jalili now alone in facing the cardiac surgeon, Pezeshkian's campaign would need to draw voters to the July 5 runoff in an election they've otherwise not taken part in as public anger hardens following years of Iran facing economic hardships and mass protests under its Shiite theocracy.\n\n\"Let's look at it as a protest in its own right: A very widespread choice to reject what's on offer - both the candidates and the system,\" said Sanam Vakil, the director of Chatham House's Middle East and North Africa program. \"That tells us a lot about public opinion and apathy, frustration. It sort of brings it all together.\"\n\nOf the 24.5 million votes cast in Friday's election, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million, election spokesman Mohsen Eslami announced. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million, while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one other runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nPHOTOS: Iran to hold runoff election with reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili after low-turnout vote\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6% turnout.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote. Jalili is known as the \"Living Martyr\" after losing a leg in the 1980s Iran-Iraq war and is famous among Western diplomats for his haranguing lectures and hard-line stances.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard and head of Iran's police, had been thought to have a wider power base, despite being plagued by corruption allegations and his role in past violent crackdowns.\n\nHe quickly endorsed Jalili in conceding the result and criticized Pezeshkian for allying himself with President Hassan Rouhani and his former foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif. The two reached Iran's 2015 nuclear deal with world powers, which later collapsed after then-President Donald Trump unilaterally withdrew from the accord.\n\n\"The road is not over yet, and despite the fact that I respect Mr. Dr. Pezeshkian personally, ... I ask all the revolutionary forces and my supporters to help stop the wave that is causing an important part of our economic and political problems today,\" Qalibaf said in a statement.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign - even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before Friday's vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nFriday's vote saw only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nThe runoff election comes as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip. In April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel. Militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons.\n\nVakil said that \"it's going to rest on if the general public, that 60% who stayed home, are going to come out and protect themselves from those hard-line views\" Jalili holds. \"That's what next Friday is going to be about.\"", The decision came after the initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win. These elections will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator, Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, the election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by the Iranian state television. He said out of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi received over 2.06 lakh votes.\n\nThe Iranian law requires the winner to get more than 50 per cent of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. {"uri": "8202158377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "01:46:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T01:46:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/586912", "title": "Iran's presidential poll heads to runoff with reformist leading first round", "body": "TEHERAN - After a highly-contested first round of presidential elections, Iran is set for a runoff vote on July 5, as none of the candidates have secured the required 50 percent of votes, Iran's Election Headquarters Spokesperson Mohsen Eslami said Saturday.\n\nThe results show that reformist Masoud Pezeshkian, Iran's former health minister, received more than 42 percent of the votes, while principlist Saeed Jalili, the former chief negotiator in the nuclear talks between Tehran and world powers, garnered over 38 percent of the total.\n\nAs per the Iranian constitution, a candidate wins the first round of the presidential election with an absolute majority of more than 50 percent. If no candidate reaches the threshold in the first round, a runoff election will be held on the Friday following the election day between the two candidates with the highest number of votes\n\nAs per the Iranian constitution, a candidate wins the first round of the presidential election with an absolute majority of more than 50 percent. If no candidate reaches the threshold in the first round, a runoff election will be held on the Friday following the election day between the two candidates with the highest number of votes.\n\nAnalysts believe that regardless of who wins in the upcoming runoff, the key focus for Iran's next president will be navigating the economic challenges posed by Western sanctions, addressing heightened tensions with Israel, and enhancing ties with neighboring countries.\n\nVoting for the election ended at 12:00 a.m. Saturday local time (2030 GMT on Friday) after 16 straight hours, being extended for three times or six hours from the scheduled closing time.\n\nTens of millions of Iranian citizens cast their ballots at close to 59,000 polling stations in more than 95 states.\n\nAccording to Iranian authorities, over 61 million people are eligible to vote in the election, but the voter turnout was only 40 percent, lower than the 48.8 percent turnout in Iran's previous presidential election in 2021.\n\nIn the lead-up to the election, the Iranian government had been actively promoting voter participation, prioritizing an increase in voter turnout. Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei has said that participation in the polls is essential \"for the viability of the Islamic Republic system.\"\n\n\"The durability, consistency, dignity and reputation of the Islamic Republic in the world depend on the presence of the people,\" he said after casting the first ballot on Friday.\n\nA total of 80 political heavyweights registered to participate in this election. Iran's Guardian Council approved six candidates earlier this month to join the race.\n\nAs Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh Hashemi, the current vice president, and Alireza Zakani, the mayor of Tehran, announced their withdrawals days before its commencement, ultimately, Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf, the parliamentary speaker; Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a former interior and justice minister, Jalili and Pezeshkian emerged as the final four contenders for Iran's highest executive office.\n\nApart from Pezeshkian and Jalili, Qalibaf received 13.8 percent of the votes, while Pourmohammadi garnered 0.8 percent, according to Iran's Election Headquarters.\n\nIran's 14th presidential election, initially set for 2025, was moved up following the unexpected death of President Ebrahim Raisi and his entourage in a helicopter crash on May 19.\n\nFollowing the incident, Khamenei reassured Iranians that there would be \"no interruption\" to the country's affairs.\n\nDuring the election, candidates have also committed to following the late President Raisi's trajectory. Nevertheless, notable disagreements persist between Pezeshkian and Jalili on matters including relations with Western nations and tackling domestic economic issues.\n\nDuring the election debates, Pezeshkian advocated for economic reforms and increased social freedom and inclusivity. He expressed his intention to achieve national economic growth through strengthening regional and global relations\n\nPezeshkian, 70, served as Iran's health minister from 2001 to 2005; he had previously worked as a heart surgeon.\n\nDuring the election debates, Pezeshkian advocated for economic reforms and increased social freedom and inclusivity. He expressed his intention to achieve national economic growth through strengthening regional and global relations.\n\nIn the final debate held on Tuesday, Pezeshkian said that \"we have to resolve our problems with the world, we have to resolve issues\" about the nuclear deal.\n\nJalili, 59, ran as a qualified candidate in the presidential elections of 2013 and 2021. In 2021, he withdrew his candidacy in support of Raisi.\n\nJalili holds a more conservative and hardline stance on relevant issues. During the debate, Jalili criticized the United States for exerting \"maximum pressure\" on Iran and said that he would not seek to improve relations with Western countries.\n\n\"We should make the enemy regretful about sanctioning Iran through economic means,\" Jalili said in the final debate, advocating for stronger economic ties with Latin American and African nations to defuse the US-led sanctions against the country.\n\nWhile most experts agree that the political direction of Iran will not undergo significant changes, Iranian citizens are still hopeful that the incoming president will implement effective solutions to tackle the country's severe economic challenges and navigate the increasing tensions with Israel and Western powers.\n\n\"The main domestic issue will be related to the economy,\" said Mostafa Khoshcheshm, a Tehran-based international affairs analyst.\n\nA recent report from the International Monetary Fund highlights Iran's dire economic situation, with domestic inflation soaring to 35 percent and unemployment at 8.9 percent. The main focus for the Iranian people now revolves around how to enhance exports, reduce inflation, and boost employment opportunities.\n\nDue to Iran's current economic hardships, largely attributed to sanctions led by the United States and Western countries, both Pezeshkian and Jalili have explicitly stated their intention to seek the lifting of US sanctions against Iran.\n\nHowever, pundits argue that because of the substantial disagreements between Iran and the United States over reviving the Iran nuclear deal, and given Iran's current tensions with Israel, prospects for a near-term improvement in Iran's relations with the West appear dim.\n\nTherefore, Iran's diplomatic focus in the future is likely to center on furthering relationships with countries in the Global South and neighboring regions.\n\n\"The most important plans to be pursued by Iran's next administration would be making full use of the country's membership in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and BRICS, the regional geopolitics and the foreign policy opportunities through further interactions with neighbors,\" said Seyed Reza Sadr al-Hosseini, a Tehran-based senior expert on regional issues.\n\n\"As stressed by the (supreme) leader (Ali Khamenei), Iran's approach will continue to be an East-oriented one regardless of who would become president,\" said Khoshcheshm.", "source": {"uri": "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/reformist-to-face-ultraconservative-in-iran-presidency-runoff/article_f201085f-20ed-548b-baf7-350b86abd7ab.html", "title": "Reformist to face ultraconservative in Iran presidency runoff", "body": "Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei waves as he casts his ballot\n\nThe sole reformist in Iran's presidential election, Masoud Pezeshkian, will face the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili in a runoff, authorities said on Saturday, following a vote marred by historically low turnout.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, secured 42.4 percent of the vote, while Jalili, a 58-year-old former nuclear negotiator, came second with 38.6 percent, according to voting figures announced by Mohsen Eslami, spokesman for Iran's elections authority.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf was next with 13.8 percent of the vote, while the only other candidate, conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, received less than one percent.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes,\" Eslami said, adding that those who finished first and second would face each other in a runoff next Friday.\n\nOnly slightly more than 40 percent of the 61 million electorate took part in Friday's first round -- a record low turnout for the Islamic republic.\n\nThe electoral authority said more than one million ballots were spoiled.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, only one has led to a runoff, which occurred in 2005.\n\nThe poll had been scheduled to take place in 2025 but was brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets candidates, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two of them -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out.\n\nBoth candidates, after the release of the final results, asked their supporters to vote for Jalili in the July 5 runoff.\n\nGhalibaf followed suit later, asking \"all revolutionary forces and supporters\" to get behind Jalili's bid for the presidency.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, the Guardian Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the election.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nMore from this section Google Tests Facial Recognition for Enhanced Office Security U.S. Mobile Carriers Hit by Global Roaming Outage Harwinton Animal Control looking for missing Peacocks\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nJalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, the reformist newspaper Sazandegi ran the headline \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run Iran daily hailed what it called a \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.\n\nrkh-pdm/dv", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
