{"uri": "2024-06-405516730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "06:26:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T06:26:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T04:57:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-saeed-jalili/article_21697121-16ad-520a-8b9c-0a7c9f04aba1.html", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "A man casts his ballot during the presidential election as he holds a picture of the late President Ebrahim Raisi in a polling station, in Tehran, Iran, Friday, June 28, 2024. Iranians were voting Friday in a snap election to replace the late President Ebrahim Raisi, killed in a helicopter crash last month, as public apathy has become pervasive in the Islamic Republic after years of economic woes, mass protests and tensions in the Middle East.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Early, seesawing results released Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men while a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nAfter counting over 14 million votes, Pezeshkian had 5.9 million while Jalili held 5.5 million.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.89 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 111,900 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains in house arrest, also has refused to vote with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nKarimi reported from Tehran, Iran.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-405420758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "03:32:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T03:32:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T03:09:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://internewscast.com/local-news/early-iran-presidential-election-results-show-strong-lead-for-saeed-jalili-according-to-state-tv/", "title": "\"Early Iran Presidential Election Results Show Strong Lead for Saeed Jalili, According to State TV\"", "body": "DUBAI - Early results in Iran's presidential election put hard-liner Saeed Jalili slightly ahead Saturday, followed closely behind by reformist Masoud Pezeshkian.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put Jalili in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy.\n\nWith over 10 million votes counted, Jaili had 4.26 million votes, followed by Pezeshkian with 4.24 million. Another candidate, hard-line speaker of the parliament Mohmmad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.38 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 80,000 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains in house arrest, also has refused to vote with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been corrected to say 10 million was the overall number of votes initially "date": "2024-05-19", "textStart": 2602, "textEnd": 2608}], "sentiment": 0.1137254901960785, "wgt": 185, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-405662171", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:56:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:56:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:44:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/iran-to-hold-runoff-election-with-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-jalili-after-low-turnout/article_21697121-16ad-520a-8b9c-0a7c9f04aba1.html", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election with reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili after low-turnout vote", "body": "A man casts his ballot during the presidential election as he holds a picture of the late President Ebrahim Raisi in a polling station, in Tehran, Iran, Friday, June 28, 2024. Iranians were voting Friday in a snap election to replace the late President Ebrahim Raisi, killed in a helicopter crash last month, as public apathy has become pervasive in the Islamic Republic after years of economic woes, mass protests and tensions in the Middle East.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Iran announced Saturday it will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6% turnout.\n\nDespite the low turnout, Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi praised the public for turning out to a vote conducted without any internationally recognized observers.\n\nHe thanked the people who voted for their \"very valuable presence,\" adding that the election was held in \"complete safety\" and \"with very serious competition.\"\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, had been thought to have a wider power base, despiting being plagued by corruption allegations. He is also known for launching a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999 and reportedly ordering live fire to be used against students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Though he has received notable endorsements from major reformist figures, including former Presidents (Hassan) Rouhani and Mohammad Khatami, Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before the vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nVahdat reported from Tehran, Iran. Nasser Karimi in Tehran, Iran, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8201374582", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:20:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:20:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:20:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/reformist-ultraconservative-qualify-for-iran-runoff-election/article_f201085f-20ed-548b-baf7-350b86abd7ab.html", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative qualify for Iran runoff election", "body": "This is the first presidential election since Iran was swept by nationwide protests over the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini after her arrest for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's dress code\n\nIran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nMore from this section Authorities: Suspect in custody following police pursuit in Tuckahoe Border Arrests Fall Over 40% Since Biden Suspended Asylum Processing US: Fan In Grimace Costume Chugs Beer During Rain Delay At Citi Field, New York 2\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were {"uri": "2024-06-405971609", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "17:40:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T17:40:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T17:40:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.chinanews.net/news/274438154/xinhua-headlines-irans-presidential-election-heads-to-runoff-with-reformist-leading-first-round", "title": "Xinhua Headlines: Iran's presidential election heads to runoff with reformist leading first round", "body": "TEHRAN, June 29 (Xinhua) -- After a highly-contested first round of presidential elections, Iran is set for a runoff vote on July 5, as none of the candidates have secured the required 50 percent of votes, Iran's Election Headquarters Spokesperson Mohsen Eslami said Saturday.\n\nThe results show that reformist Masoud Pezeshkian, Iran's former health minister, received more than 42 percent of the votes, while principlist Saeed Jalili, the former chief negotiator in the nuclear talks between Tehran and world powers, garnered over 38 percent of the total.\n\nAs per the Iranian constitution, a candidate wins the first round of the presidential election with an absolute majority of more than 50 percent. If no candidate reaches the threshold in the first round, a runoff election will be held on the Friday following the election day between the two candidates with the highest number of votes.\n\nAnalysts believe that regardless of who wins in the upcoming runoff, the key focus for Iran's next president will be navigating the economic challenges posed by Western sanctions, addressing heightened tensions with Israel, and enhancing ties with neighboring countries. LOW TURNOUT\n\nVoting for the election ended at 12:00 a.m. Saturday local time (2030 GMT on Friday) after 16 straight hours, being extended for three times or six hours from the scheduled closing time.\n\nTens of millions of Iranian citizens cast their ballots at close to 59,000 polling stations in more than 95 states.\n\nAccording to Iranian authorities, over 61 million people are eligible to vote in the election, but the voter turnout was only 40 percent, lower than the 48.8 percent turnout in Iran's previous presidential election in 2021.\n\nIn the lead-up to the election, the Iranian government had been actively promoting voter participation, prioritizing an increase in voter turnout. Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei has said that participation in the polls is essential \"for the viability of the Islamic Republic system.\"\n\n\"The durability, consistency, dignity and reputation of the Islamic Republic in the world depend on the presence of the people,\" he said after casting the first ballot on Friday.\n\nA total of 80 political heavyweights registered to participate in this election. Iran's Guardian Council approved six candidates earlier this month to join the race.\n\nAs Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh Hashemi, the current vice president, and Alireza Zakani, the mayor of Tehran, announced their withdrawals days before its commencement, ultimately, Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf, the parliamentary speaker; Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a former interior and justice minister, Jalili and Pezeshkian emerged as the final four contenders for Iran's highest executive office.\n\nApart from Pezeshkian and Jalili, Qalibaf received 13.8 percent of the votes, while Pourmohammadi garnered 0.8 percent, according to Iran's Election Headquarters. REFORMIST VS PRINCIPLIST\n\nIran's 14th presidential election, initially set for 2025, was moved up following the unexpected death of President Ebrahim Raisi and his entourage in a helicopter crash on May 19.\n\nFollowing the incident, Khamenei reassured Iranians that there would be \"no interruption\" to the country's affairs.\n\nDuring the election, candidates have also committed to following the late President Raisi's trajectory. Nevertheless, notable disagreements persist between Pezeshkian and Jalili on matters including relations with Western nations and tackling domestic economic issues.\n\nPezeshkian, 70, served as Iran's health minister from 2001 to 2005; he had previously worked as a heart surgeon.\n\nDuring the election debates, Pezeshkian advocated for economic reforms and increased social freedom and inclusivity. He expressed his intention to achieve national economic growth through strengthening regional and global relations.\n\nIn the final debate held on Tuesday, Pezeshkian said that \"we have to resolve our problems with the world, we have to resolve issues\" about the nuclear deal.\n\nJalili, 59, ran as a qualified candidate in the presidential elections of 2013 and 2021. In 2021, he withdrew his candidacy in support of Raisi.\n\nJalili holds a more conservative and hardline stance on relevant issues. During the debate, Jalili criticized the United States for exerting \"maximum pressure\" on Iran and said that he would not seek to improve relations with Western countries.\n\n\"We should make the enemy regretful about sanctioning Iran through economic means,\" Jalili said in the final debate, advocating for stronger economic ties with Latin American and African nations to defuse the U.S.-led sanctions against the country. FUTURE PATH\n\nWhile most experts agree that the political direction of Iran will not undergo significant changes, Iranian citizens are still hopeful that the incoming president will implement effective solutions to tackle the country's severe economic challenges and navigate the increasing tensions with Israel and Western powers.\n\n\"The main domestic issue will be related to the economy,\" said Mostafa Khoshcheshm, a Tehran-based international affairs analyst.\n\nA recent report from the International Monetary Fund highlights Iran's dire economic situation, with domestic inflation soaring to 35 percent and unemployment at 8.9 percent. The main focus for the Iranian people now revolves around how to enhance exports, reduce inflation, and boost employment opportunities.\n\nDue to Iran's current economic hardships, largely attributed to sanctions led by the United States and Western countries, both Pezeshkian and Jalili have explicitly stated their intention to seek the lifting of U.S. sanctions against Iran.\n\nHowever, pundits argue that because of the substantial disagreements between Iran and the United States over reviving the Iran nuclear deal, and given Iran's current tensions with Israel, prospects for a near-term improvement in Iran's relations with the West appear dim.\n\nTherefore, Iran's diplomatic focus in the future is likely to center on furthering relationships with countries in the Global South and neighboring regions.\n\n\"The most important plans to be pursued by Iran's next administration would be making full use of the country's membership in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and BRICS, the regional geopolitics and the foreign policy opportunities through further interactions with neighbors,\" said Seyed Reza Sadr al-Hosseini, a Tehran-based senior expert on regional issues.\n\n\"As stressed by the (supreme) leader (Ali Khamenei), Iran's approach will continue to be an East-oriented one regardless of who would become president,\" said Khoshcheshm.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201316861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:28:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:28:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:28:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/reformist-ultraconservative-lead-iran-presidential-vote/article_f201085f-20ed-548b-baf7-350b86abd7ab.html", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative lead Iran presidential vote", "body": "This is the first presidential election since Iran was swept by nationwide protests over the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini after her arrest for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's dress code\n\nIran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili are leading in snap presidential elections, according to early results on Saturday from the Interior Ministry.\n\nAccording to the latest count, Pezeshkian has won more than 8,300,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has over 7,100,000.\n\nShould the current trend continue, both candidates would head into a runoff set for July 5. The second round is required if no candidate wins 50 percent of the vote, plus one.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nThe Interior Ministry reported that more than 19,000,000 ballots had been counted so far.\n\nComing third in the early results is the conservative parliament speaker, Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, with about 2,600,000 votes.\n\nThe fourth, Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 158,314 votes.\n\nAround 61 million Iranians were eligible to cast ballots in the elections that were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent -- the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nMore from this section Why do Americans love watching movies with their dogs? Nike shares tumble on tepid outlook as CEO eyes Olympics marketing win Emotional day on Manitoba First Nation, as city apologizes for racist expulsion order more than a century ago - Different camps -\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European capitals in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.\n\nrkh/mz/jsa", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-06-406081342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "21:29:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T21:29:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T21:16:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://dailytimes.com.pk/1205085/iran-to-hold-runoff-election/", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election", "body": "Iran announced Saturday it will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes. Iranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race\u00b4s top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There\u00b4s been only one runoff presidential election in Iran\u00b4s history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates. The overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6% turnout.\n\nDespite the low turnout, Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi praised the public for turning out to a vote conducted without any internationally recognized observers.\n\nHe thanked the people who voted for their \"very valuable presence,\" adding that the election was held in \"complete safety\" and \"with very serious competition.\"\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere\u00b4s also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian\u00b4s generation had in the 1979 revolution. Jalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, had been thought to have a wider power base, despiting being plagued by corruption allegations. He is also known for launching a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999 and reportedly ordering live fire to be used against students in 2003 while serving as the country\u00b4s police chief.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. \"Though he has received notable endorsements from major reformist figures, including former Presidents (Hassan) Rouhani and Mohammad Khatami, Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before the vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country\u00b4s foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen\u00b4s Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons.", "source": {"uri": "dailytimes.com.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-405699103", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:47:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:47:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:03:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/reformist-ultraconservative-qualify-for-iran-runoff-election/article_8db1a95e-0fca-5130-94ec-57786daf307c.html", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative qualify for Iran runoff election", "body": "This is the first presidential election since Iran was swept by nationwide protests over the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini after her arrest for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's dress code\n\nIran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili have qualified for a runoff presidential election after leading in the first round, an official said on Saturday.\n\nPezeshkian got more than 10,400,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has more than 9,400,000, said Mohsen Eslami, spokesman of Iran's election authority.\n\n\"None of the candidates could garner the absolute majority of the votes, therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nOut of around 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he added, with a turnout of around 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 206,397 votes.\n\nThe election authority counted a total of 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.\n\nrkh-pdm/mz/jsa\n\nMore from this section\n\nEmpowering Women To Improve Their Inner Health\n\nOld Vine Registry Marks One Year Anniversary and Announces Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line speaker of the parliament Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.6 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 95,000 votes.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIt did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Early results in Iran's presidential election put hard-liner Saeed Jalili slightly ahead Saturday, followed closely behind by reformist Masoud Pezeshkian.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put Jalili in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWith over 10 million votes counted, Jaili had 4.26 million votes, followed by Pezeshkian with 4.24 million. Another candidate, hard-line speaker of the parliament Mohmmad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.38 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 80,000 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains in house arrest, also has refused to vote with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been corrected to say 10 million was the overall number of votes initially {"uri": "8202149915", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "01:32:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T01:32:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:31:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "http://www.china.org.cn/world/2024-06/30/content_117282654.htm", "title": "Iran's presidential election heads to runoff with reformist leading first round", "body": "After a highly-contested first round of presidential elections, Iran is set for a runoff vote on July 5, as none of the candidates have secured the required 50 percent of votes, Iran's Election Headquarters Spokesperson Mohsen Eslami said Saturday.\n\nThe results show that reformist Masoud Pezeshkian, Iran's former health minister, received more than 42 percent of the votes, while principlist Saeed Jalili, the former chief negotiator in the nuclear talks between Tehran and world powers, garnered over 38 percent of the total.\n\nAs per the Iranian constitution, a candidate wins the first round of the presidential election with an absolute majority of more than 50 percent. If no candidate reaches the threshold in the first round, a runoff election will be held on the Friday following the election day between the two candidates with the highest number of votes.\n\nAnalysts believe that regardless of who wins in the upcoming runoff, the key focus for Iran's next president will be navigating the economic challenges posed by Western sanctions, addressing heightened tensions with Israel, and enhancing ties with neighboring countries.\n\nLOW TURNOUT\n\nVoting for the election ended at 12:00 a.m. Saturday local time (2030 GMT on Friday) after 16 straight hours, being extended for three times or six hours from the scheduled closing time.\n\nTens of millions of Iranian citizens cast their ballots at close to 59,000 polling stations in more than 95 states.\n\nAccording to Iranian authorities, over 61 million people are eligible to vote in the election, but the voter turnout was only 40 percent, lower than the 48.8 percent turnout in Iran's previous presidential election in 2021.\n\nPeople vote at a polling station during Iran's presidential election in Tehran, Iran, June 28, 2024. (Xinhua/Shadati)\n\nIn the lead-up to the election, the Iranian government had been actively promoting voter participation, prioritizing an increase in voter turnout. Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei has said that participation in the polls is essential \"for the viability of the Islamic Republic system.\"\n\n\"The durability, consistency, dignity and reputation of the Islamic Republic in the world depend on the presence of the people,\" he said after casting the first ballot on Friday.\n\nA total of 80 political heavyweights registered to participate in this election. Iran's Guardian Council approved six candidates earlier this month to join the race.\n\nAs Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh Hashemi, the current vice president, and Alireza Zakani, the mayor of Tehran, announced their withdrawals days before its commencement, ultimately, Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf, the parliamentary speaker; Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a former interior and justice minister, Jalili and Pezeshkian emerged as the final four contenders for Iran's highest executive office.\n\nApart from Pezeshkian and Jalili, Qalibaf received 13.8 percent of the votes, while Pourmohammadi garnered 0.8 percent, according to Iran's Election Headquarters.\n\nA voter casts his ballot for Iran's presidential election at a polling station in Tehran, Iran, June 28, 2024. (Xinhua/Shadati)\n\nREFORMIST VS PRINCIPLIST\n\nIran's 14th presidential election, initially set for 2025, was moved up following the unexpected death of President Ebrahim Raisi and his entourage in a helicopter crash on May 19.\n\nFollowing the incident, Khamenei reassured Iranians that there would be \"no interruption\" to the country's affairs.\n\nDuring the election, candidates have also committed to following the late President Raisi's trajectory. Nevertheless, notable disagreements persist between Pezeshkian and Jalili on matters including relations with Western nations and tackling domestic economic issues.\n\nPezeshkian, 70, served as Iran's health minister from 2001 to 2005; he had previously worked as a heart surgeon.\n\nDuring the election debates, Pezeshkian advocated for economic reforms and increased social freedom and inclusivity. He expressed his intention to achieve national economic growth through strengthening regional and global relations.\n\nIn the final debate held on Tuesday, Pezeshkian said that \"we have to resolve our problems with the world, we have to resolve issues\" about the nuclear deal.\n\nJalili, 59, ran as a qualified candidate in the presidential elections of 2013 and 2021. In 2021, he withdrew his candidacy in support of Raisi.\n\nJalili holds a more conservative and hardline stance on relevant issues. During the debate, Jalili criticized the United States for exerting \"maximum pressure\" on Iran and said that he would not seek to improve relations with Western countries.\n\n\"We should make the enemy regretful about sanctioning Iran through economic means,\" Jalili said in the final debate, advocating for stronger economic ties with Latin American and African nations to defuse the U.S.-led sanctions against the country.\n\nSnow mountains are seen from Tehran, Iran, March 9, 2024. (Xinhua/Shadati)\n\nFUTURE PATH\n\nWhile most experts agree that the political direction of Iran will not undergo significant changes, Iranian citizens are still hopeful that the incoming president will implement effective solutions to tackle the country's severe economic challenges and navigate the increasing tensions with Israel and Western powers.\n\n\"The main domestic issue will be related to the economy,\" said Mostafa Khoshcheshm, a Tehran-based international affairs analyst.\n\nA recent report from the International Monetary Fund highlights Iran's dire economic situation, with domestic inflation soaring to 35 percent and unemployment at 8.9 percent. The main focus for the Iranian people now revolves around how to enhance exports, reduce inflation, and boost employment opportunities.\n\nDue to Iran's current economic hardships, largely attributed to sanctions led by the United States and Western countries, both Pezeshkian and Jalili have explicitly stated their intention to seek the lifting of U.S. sanctions against Iran.\n\nHowever, pundits argue that because of the substantial disagreements between Iran and the United States over reviving the Iran nuclear deal, and given Iran's current tensions with Israel, prospects for a near-term improvement in Iran's relations with the West appear dim.\n\nTherefore, Iran's diplomatic focus in the future is likely to center on furthering relationships with countries in the Global South and neighboring regions.\n\n\"The most important plans to be pursued by Iran's next administration would be making full use of the country's membership in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and BRICS, the regional geopolitics and the foreign policy opportunities through further interactions with neighbors,\" said Seyed Reza Sadr al-Hosseini, a Tehran-based senior expert on regional issues.\n\n\"As stressed by the (supreme) leader (Ali Khamenei), Iran's approach will continue to be an East-oriented one regardless of who would become president,\" said Khoshcheshm.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-405632950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:16:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:16:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:04:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/election-outcome-in-iran-sets-the-stage-for-a-competition-between-reformist-pezeshkian-and-conservative-jalili/", "title": "Election outcome in Iran sets the stage for a competition between reformist Pezeshkian and conservative Jalili", "body": "Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men while a run-off vote appeared likely.\n\nIranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nAfter counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, also has refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8201244552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:24:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:24:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:23:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/middle-east/iran-goes-to-a-runoff-election-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-saeed-jalili/article_b07ac750-6e06-5c74-a10a-8e89aede2bea.html", "title": "Iran goes to a runoff election between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Iran will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi, an official said Saturday, after an initial vote saw the top candidates not secure an outright win.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRaisi, a 63-year-old prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, died in a helicopter crash in May.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between little-known reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men as a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nIranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi who died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nSo far, no turnout figures have been offered -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAfter counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million. Another candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nVahdat {"uri": "2024-06-405586500", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:11:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:11:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T07:49:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-jalili/article_21697121-16ad-520a-8b9c-0a7c9f04aba1.html", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili", "body": "A man casts his ballot during the presidential election as he holds a picture of the late President Ebrahim Raisi in a polling station, in Tehran, Iran, Friday, June 28, 2024. Iranians were voting Friday in a snap election to replace the late President Ebrahim Raisi, killed in a helicopter crash last month, as public apathy has become pervasive in the Islamic Republic after years of economic woes, mass protests and tensions in the Middle East.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between little-known reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men as a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nIranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi who died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nSo far, no turnout figures have been offered -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon.\n\nAfter counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million. Another candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nKarimi reported from Tehran, Iran.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201519440", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:35:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:35:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T12:35:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/world/iran-hold-runoff-election-reformist-pezeshkian-hard-liner-jalili-after-low-turnout-vote-887461", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election with reformist Pezeshkian, hard-liner", "body": "Iran announced today (29 June) it will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6% turnout.\n\nDespite the low turnout, Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi praised the public for turning out to a vote conducted without any internationally recognized observers.\n\nHe thanked the people who voted for their \"very valuable presence,\" adding that the election was held in \"complete safety\" and \"with very serious competition.\"\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, had been thought to have a wider power base, despiting being plagued by corruption allegations. He is also known for launching a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999 and reportedly ordering live fire to be used against students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Though he has received notable endorsements from major reformist figures, including former Presidents (Hassan) Rouhani and Mohammad Khatami, Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before the vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.", "source": {"uri": "tbsnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8201138768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "06:43:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T06:43:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T06:43:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-saeed-jalili/articleshow/111358012.cms", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili - Times of India", "body": "DUBAI: Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men while a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nIranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet - a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nAfter counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, also has refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a protege of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news",
