{"uri": "8201629684", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "14:25:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T14:25:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T14:25:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/iran-to-hold-runoff-election-with-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-jalili-after-low-turnout-vote-1.6946274", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election with reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili after low-turnout vote", "body": "Iran will hold a runoff presidential election pitting a little-known reformist against a hard-line former nuclear negotiator after results released Saturday showed the lowest-ever poll turnout in the Islamic Republic's history.\n\nMore than 60 per cent of voters cast no ballot in the race that saw reformist Masoud Pezeshkian best Saeed Jalili, who competed alongside two other hard-liners.\n\nWith Jalili now alone in facing the cardiac surgeon, Pezeshkian's campaign would need to draw voters to the July 5 runoff in an election they've otherwise not taken part in as public anger hardens following years of Iran facing economic hardships and mass protests under its Shiite theocracy.\n\n\"Let's look at it as a protest in its own right: A very widespread choice to reject what's on offer -- both the candidates and the system,\" said Sanam Vakil, the director of Chatham House's Middle East and North Africa program. \"That tells us a lot about public opinion and apathy, frustration. It sort of brings it all together.\"\n\nOf the 24.5 million votes cast in Friday's election, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million, election spokesman Mohsen Eslami announced. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million, while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50 per cent of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one other runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than one million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9 per cent, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8 per cent turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6 per cent turnout.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote. Jalili is known as the \"Living Martyr\" after losing a leg in the 1980s Iran-Iraq war and is famous among Western diplomats for his haranguing lectures and hard-line stances.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard and head of Iran's police, had been thought to have a wider power base, despite being plagued by corruption allegations and his role in past violent crackdowns.\n\nHe quickly endorsed Jalili in conceding the result and criticized Pezeshkian for allying himself with President Hassan Rouhani and his former foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif. The two reached Iran's 2015 nuclear deal with world powers, which later collapsed after then-President Donald Trump unilaterally withdrew from the accord.\n\n\"The road is not over yet, and despite the fact that I respect Mr. Dr. Pezeshkian personally, (...) I ask all the revolutionary forces and my supporters to help stop the wave that is causing an important part of our economic and political problems today,\" Qalibaf said in a statement.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting, seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before Friday's vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a protege of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nFriday's vote saw only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nThe runoff election comes as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip. In April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel. Militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nVakil said that \"it's going to rest on if the general public, that 60 per cent who stayed home, are going to come out and protect themselves from those hard-line views\" Jalili holds. \"That's what next Friday is going to be about.\"", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election", {"uri": "2024-06-405660984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:55:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:55:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:03:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/reformist-ultraconservative-lead-iran-presidential-vote/article_8db1a95e-0fca-5130-94ec-57786daf307c.html", "title": "Reformist, ultraconservative lead Iran presidential vote", "body": "This is the first presidential election since Iran was swept by nationwide protests over the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini after her arrest for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's dress code\n\nIran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili are leading in snap presidential elections, according to early results on Saturday from the Interior Ministry.\n\nAccording to the latest count, Pezeshkian has won more than 8,300,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has over 7,100,000.\n\nShould the current trend continue, both candidates would head into a runoff set for July 5. The second round is required if no candidate wins 50 percent of the vote, plus one.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one has led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nThe Interior Ministry reported that more than 19,000,000 ballots had been counted so far.\n\nComing third in the early results is the conservative parliament speaker, Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, with about 2,600,000 votes.\n\nThe fourth, Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 158,314 votes.\n\nAround 61 million Iranians were eligible to cast ballots in the elections that were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent -- the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear programme and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of elections.\n\n- Different camps -\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticised Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European capitals in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation\".\n\nUltraconservative Jalili, Iran's former nuclear negotiator, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, Iran's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeast Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nTwo policemen were killed and others were injured in the attack, the agency added.\n\nrkh/mz/jsa\n\nMore from this section\n\nCome Over October 2024 Campaign Officially Announced\n\nScientology Network Anti-Drug Marathon Focuses on the Power of Prevention\n\nThe Mortgage Collaborative Advocates for Lender Concerns at Federal Housing Agencies During June DC Visits", {"uri": "8201218796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:01:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:01:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:00:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/29/iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hardliner-jalili/", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Jon Gambrell And Nasser Karimi, The Associated Press on June 29, 2024.\n\nIn this photo provided by Iranian Students' News Agency, ISNA, hard-line former Iranian senior nuclear negotiator and candidate for the presidential election Saeed Jalili casts his ballot in a polling station, in Tehran, Iran, Friday, June 28, 2024. Iranians are voting in a snap election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi. (Alireza Sotakabr, ISNA via AP)DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between little-known reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men as a runoff vote appeared likely. Iranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi who died in a helicopter crash last month. So far, no turnout figures have been offered - a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests. Voters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. After counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million. Another candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes. Iranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors. There had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said. There's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\"\u009d of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution. Raisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab. The voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip. In April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks. Meanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons. Despite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers. ___ Karimi reported from Tehran, Iran.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201099222", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "06:02:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T06:02:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T06:02:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/see-saw-vote-in-iran-narrows-presidential-race-to-two-in-neck-and-neck-count-1643982.html", "title": "See-saw vote in Iran narrows presidential race to two in neck-and-neck count | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Early results released on Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and conservative hard-line candidate Saeed Jalili.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election to replace the late hard-line president Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nAfter counting more than 14 million votes, Mr Pezeshkian had 5.9 million, while Mr Jalili held 5.5 million.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.89 million votes.\n\nShiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 111,900 votes. Voters chose between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Mr Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, and the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognised monitors.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast.\n\nIf that does not happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later.\n\nThere's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe late president Mr Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others.\n\nHe was seen as a protege of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor.\n\nStill, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988 and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9692323", "eventUri": "eng-9692323", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-19", "textStart": 1589, "textEnd": {"uri": "8201340429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:50:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:50:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:50:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/iran-to-hold-runoff-election-with-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-jalili-after-low-turnout/article_202d4006-e7e9-50f5-8c82-4c1ba2a289f4.html", "title": "Iran to hold runoff election with reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili after low-turnout vote", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Iran announced Saturday it will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6% turnout.\n\nDespite the low turnout, Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi praised the public for turning out to a vote conducted without any internationally recognized observers.\n\nHe thanked the people who voted for their \"very valuable presence,\" adding that the election was held in \"complete safety\" and \"with very serious competition.\"\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, had been thought to have a wider power base, despiting being plagued by corruption allegations. He is also known for launching a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999 and reportedly ordering live fire to be used against students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Though he has received notable endorsements from major reformist figures, including former Presidents (Hassan) Rouhani and Mohammad Khatami, Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before the vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nVahdat reported from Tehran, Iran. Nasser Karimi in Tehran, Iran, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "news-gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8201037701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "04:56:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T04:56:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T04:55:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/world/Iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-Masoud-Pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-Saeed-Jalili", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "Early, seesawing results released Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men while a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nAfter counting over 12 million votes, Pezeshkian had over 5 million while Jalili held 4.8 million.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line speaker of the parliament Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.6 million votes. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 95,000 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains in house arrest, also has refused to vote with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\n\u00a9 Copyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.", "source": {"uri": "japantoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Japan Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masoud_Pezeshkian", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Masoud Pezeshkian"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saeed_Jalili", {"uri": "2024-06-406142815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "00:30:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T00:30:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T00:29:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.industriesnews.net/news/274437978/iranian-presidential-election-heads-into-runoff", "title": "Iranian presidential election heads into runoff", "body": "The vote was called after the death of President Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash in May\n\nIran will hold a second round of its presidential election after none of the candidates secured enough votes for victory during Friday's ballot, the Interior Ministry has said.\n\nThe snap election was called after the death of President Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash in Iran's East Azerbaijan Province on May 19.\n\nThe results of the first round mean that two of the candidates - reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and conservative Saeed Jalili - will compete in a runoff, Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi said on Saturday.\n\nWith all ballots counted, Pezeshkian secured 10.4 million votes (42.45%), with Jalili on 9.5 million votes (38.61%).\n\nTheir two other contenders - Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf and Mostafa Pourmohammadi - fell out of the race, with 13.78% and 0.84% of ballots, respectively.\n\nAccording to Iranian law, a candidate needs to garner at least 50% plus 1 vote to be declared president.\n\nTurnout stood at 24.5 million, or 40% of the 61 million people eligible to vote. The second round will be held on Friday, July 5, according to the interior minister.\n\nREAD MORE: Five conservatives, one reformer: Who is running for power in Iran's presidential elections\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon-turned-politician, who served as health minister in the 2000s and as first deputy speaker of parliament from 2016 to 2020. The two candidates will now face a runoff to determine who will assume the country's top executive position.\n\nEslami added the other two candidates, Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, collected 3,383,340 (13.8 percent) and 206,397 (0.8 percent) votes respectively.\n\nHe put the total number of votes at 24,535,185, noting that the turnout stood at 40 percent.\n\nThe voting for the presidential election began at 8:00 a.m. Friday local time (0430 GMT) at 58,640 polling stations across the country and abroad, and lasted until midnight, after being extended three times, with each extension lasting for two hours.\n\nIran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei cast the first ballot at a polling station and made a brief speech calling for the unity of the Iranian people during the election.\n\nTo secure the presidency, a candidate must obtain more than 50 percent of the total votes in the first round. For the run-off, whoever gets more votes will claim the victory.\n\nCurrently serving as a lawmaker, Pezeshkian previously held the position of health minister. {"uri": "8201269612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:48:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:48:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T08:47:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/iran-goes-to-a-runoff-election-between-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-jalili/article_202d4006-e7e9-50f5-8c82-4c1ba2a289f4.html", "title": "Iran goes to a runoff election between reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Iran will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi, an official said Saturday, after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic by percentage.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 42% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 41% turnout.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nVahdat reported from Tehran, Iran. Nasser Karimi in Tehran, Iran, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "news-gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-405593875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "08:22:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T08:22:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T07:49:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2024/06/29/iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hardliner-jalili/", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) - Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between little-known reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men as a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nIranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi who died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nSo far, no turnout figures have been offered - a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon.\n\nAfter counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million. Another candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\"\u009d of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build - should it choose to do so - several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. {"uri": "8201571617", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "13:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T13:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T13:26:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-iran-to-hold-runoff-election-with-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-jalili-after-low-turnout-vote-6073959.html", "title": "World News | Iran to Hold Runoff Election with Reformist Pezeshkian and Hard-liner Jalili After Low-turnout Vote | LatestLY", "body": "Dubai, Jun 29 (AP) Iran will hold a runoff presidential election pitting a little-known reformist against a hard-line former nuclear negotiator after results released Saturday showed the lowest-ever poll turnout in the Islamic Republic's history.\n\nMore than 60% of voters cast no ballot in the race that saw reformist Masoud Pezeshkian best Saeed Jalili, who competed alongside two other hard-liners.\n\nAlso Read | US: Woman Charged With Manslaughter After Leaving Eight-Year-Old Daughter in Hot Car While She Worked in Charlotte.\n\nWith Jalili now alone in facing the cardiac surgeon, Pezeshkian's campaign would need to draw voters to the July 5 runoff in an election they've otherwise not taken part in as public anger hardens following years of Iran facing economic hardships and mass protests under its Shiite theocracy.\n\n\"Let's look at it as a protest in its own right: A very widespread choice to reject what's on offer - both the candidates and the system,\" said Sanam Vakil, the director of Chatham House's Middle East and North Africa program.\n\nAlso Read | North Korea Executes 22-Year-Old Man for Listening to K-Pop Songs and Watching South Korean Films: Report.\n\n\"That tells us a lot about public opinion and apathy, frustration. It sort of brings it all together.\"\n\nOf the 24.5 million votes cast in Friday's election, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million, election spokesman Mohsen Eslami announced. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million, while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one other runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 48.8% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 40.6% turnout.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, once described by CIA director Bill Burns as \"stupefyingly opaque\" in negotiations, likely would have won outright had the three hard-liners not split Friday's vote. Jalili is known as the \"Living Martyr\" after losing a leg in the 1980s Iran-Iraq war and is famous among Western diplomats for his haranguing lectures and hard-line stances.\n\nQalibaf, a former general in Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard and head of Iran's police, had been thought to have a wider power base, despite being plagued by corruption allegations and his role in past violent crackdowns.\n\nHe quickly endorsed Jalili in conceding the result and criticized Pezeshkian for allying himself with President Hassan Rouhani and his former foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif. The two reached Iran's 2015 nuclear deal with world powers, which later collapsed after then-President Donald Trump unilaterally withdrew from the accord.\n\n\"The road is not over yet, and despite the fact that I respect Mr. Dr. Pezeshkian personally, ... I ask all the revolutionary forces and my supporters to help stop the wave that is causing an important part of our economic and political problems today,\" Qalibaf said in a statement.\n\nNow the question becomes whether Pezeshkian will be able to draw voters into his campaign. On Election Day, he offered comments on outreach to the West after voting seemingly aimed at drumming up turnout for his campaign -- even after being targeted by a veiled warning from Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\n\"Pezeshkian has been a generally underwhelming candidate,\" the geopolitical consultancy Eurasia Group said in an analysis before Friday's vote. \"Should he qualify for a runoff, his position would weaken as the conservative voting bloc unites behind a single candidate.\"\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nFriday's vote saw only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nThe runoff election comes as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip. In April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel. Militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nVakil said that \"it's going to rest on if the general public, that 60% who stayed home, are going to come out and protect themselves from those hard-line views\" Jalili holds. \"That's what next Friday is going to be about.\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masoud_Pezeshkian", "type": "person", Therefore, the first and second contenders who got the most votes will be referred\" for the second round, scheduled for next Friday, Eslami told a press conference.\n\nREAD ALL ABOUT IT The front pages of Iran's newspapers reporting about the Islamic republic's elections are pictured in the capital Tehran on June 29, 2024, a day after the polls. AFP PHOTO\n\nOut of about 61 million eligible voters, some 24,500,000 voters headed to the polls, he said, with a turnout of about 40 percent -- the lowest yet in the history of the Islamic republic.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nOut of Iran's 13 previous presidential elections since the Islamic revolution in 1979, only one had led to runoffs in 2005.\n\nConservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf received about 3,383,340 votes, and conservative cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had 206,397.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe poll authority counted 1,056,159 spoiled ballots.\n\nThe elections were originally scheduled for 2025 but were brought forward by the death of ultraconservative president Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- Tehran's ultraconservative Mayor Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun the polls.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, which at the time was the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nFriday's vote took place amid heightened regional tensions over the war in the Gaza Strip, a dispute with the West over Iran's nuclear program and domestic discontent over the state of Iran's sanctions-hit economy.\n\nIran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei had called on people to participate in the vote.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOpposition groups, especially in the diaspora, meanwhile called for a boycott, questioning the credibility of the elections.\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is a heart surgeon who has represented the northern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe served as health minister under Iran's last reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who held office from 1997 to 2005 and has endorsed Pezeshkian's bid in the current elections.\n\nPezeshkian criticized Raisi's government for a lack of transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death of Mahsa Amini in police custody.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, had been arrested for allegedly violating the Islamic republic's strict dress code for women.\n\nIn recent campaigning, Pezeshkian called for \"constructive relations\" with Washington and European countries in order to \"get Iran out of its isolation.\"\n\nHis rival, Jalili, has maintained his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nThe 58-year-old has held several senior positions in the Islamic republic, including in Khamenei's office in the early 2000s.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHe is currently one of Khamenei's representatives in the Supreme National Security Council, the country's highest security body.\n\nOn Saturday, Iranian reformist daily Sazandegi posted \"Long live hope\" on its front page, while the state-run daily Iran hailed the \"strong\" turnout.\n\nRegardless of the result, Iran's next president will be in charge of applying state policy outlined by the supreme leader, who wields ultimate authority in the country.\n\nEarlier, the local Tasnim news agency said militants in southeastern Iran attacked a vehicle carrying ballot boxes in Sistan-Baluchistan province.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTwo policemen were killed, and others were injured in the attack, it added.", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", {"uri": "8201206256", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "07:48:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T07:48:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T07:48:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/iran-seesawing-vote-results-put-race-between-reformist-masoud-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-saeed-jalili/article_202d4006-e7e9-50f5-8c82-4c1ba2a289f4.html", "title": "Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Seesawing results released early Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between little-known reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men as a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nIranian state television reported the results which did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a second round of voting to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi who died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nSo far, no turnout figures have been offered -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its Shiite theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon.\n\nAfter counting over 19 million votes, Pezeshkian had 8.3 million while Jalili held 7.18 million. Another candidate, hard-line parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 2.67 million votes while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 158,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nKarimi reported from Tehran, Iran.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201027708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "04:42:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T04:42:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T04:42:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/5035252", "title": "Iran Vote Results Put Race Between Reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and Hard-Liner Saeed Jalili", "body": "An electoral staff empties full ballot boxes after voting ended at a polling station, in a snap presidential election to choose a successor to Ebrahim Raisi following his death in a helicopter crash, in Tehran, Iran June 29, 2024. Majid Asgaripour/WANA (West Asia News Agency) via REUTERS\n\nEarly, seesawing results released Saturday in Iran's presidential election put the race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili, with the lead trading between the two men while a runoff vote appeared likely.\n\nThe early results, reported by Iranian state television, did not initially put either man in a position to win Friday's election outright, potentially setting the stage for a runoff election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi, The Associated Press said.\n\nIt also did not offer any turnout figures for the race yet -- a crucial component of whether Iran's electorate backs its theocracy after years of economic turmoil and mass protests.\n\nAfter counting over 12 million votes, Pezeshkian had over 5 million while Jalili held 4.8 million.\n\nAnother candidate, hard-line speaker of the parliament Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, had some 1.6 million votes. Cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had more than 95,000 votes.\n\nVoters faced a choice between the three hard-line candidates and the little-known reformist Pezeshkian, a heart surgeon. As has been the case since the 1979 Iranian Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi militants -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains in house arrest, also has refused to vote with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. One woman in a documentary on Pezeshkian aired by state TV said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If that doesn't happen, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nThe 63-year-old Raisi died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. After counting 24,535,185 votes, Pezeshkian is ahead with 10,415,991 votes while Jalili has 9,473,298.\n\nAnother candidate, Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, has 3,383,340 votes while Mostafa Pourmohammadi has 206,397.\n\nAmirhossein Ghazizadeh Hashemi and Alireza Zakani had dropped their candidacy before the election.\n\nUnder Iranian electoral law, a runoff between the two top candidates is held on the first Friday after the result is announced if neither wins at least 50% of the votes.\n\nOn May 19, 2024, a helicopter carrying late Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi, late Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian, and several other officials crashed while flying from Khudafarin to Tabriz, and the Iranian president and the entire accompanying delegation were martyred.\n\n7129**4354", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-406057802", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "20:31:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T20:31:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T20:22:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/2024-06-29/irans-presidential-election-to-face-second-vote-after-low-turnout", "title": "Iran's presidential election to face second vote after low turnout", "body": "Iran will hold a run-off presidential vote between reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and hardline Saeed Jalili, as results showed the lowest-ever poll turnout in the Islamic Republic's history.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates advance to a runoff a week later.\n\nFormer nuclear negotiator Jalili was trailing cardiac surgeon Pezeshkian, but both were around the 40% mark.\n\nOf the 24.5 million votes cast in Friday's election, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million, election spokesman Mohsen Eslami announced.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million, while Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nA run-off election date has been set for July 5.\n\nMore than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results.\n\nThere's been only one other runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million.\n\nParliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later.\n\nThere's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi saw a 42% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 41% turnout.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been {"uri": "8201163388", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "07:08:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T07:08:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T07:08:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.northernirelandnews.com/news/274437759/sole-moderate-candidate-leads-iran-presidential-vote-amid-low-turnout", "title": "Sole moderate candidate leads Iran presidential vote amid low turnout", "body": "dubai, united arab emirates - The low-key moderate candidate is leading the vote count in Iran's snap presidential election among a tightly controlled group of four candidates loyal to the supreme leader at a time of growing public frustration and Western pressure.\n\nWith more than 3.8 million ballots from Friday's election counted so far, Massoud Pezeshkian won over 1,595,000 votes, while his hardline challenger former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili gained about 1,594,000, Interior ministry official Mohsen Eslami told state TV early Saturday.\n\nWhile some insiders said the turnout was around 40%, lower than expected by Iran's clerical rulers, witnesses told Reuters that polling stations in Tehran and some other cities were not crowded.\n\nIran's Tasnim news agency said a run-off election was 'very likely' to pick the next president following the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash.\n\nVote unlikely to shift policies\n\nThe election coincides with escalating regional tension due to the war between Israel and Iranian allies Hamas in Gaza and Hezbollah in Lebanon, as well as increased Western pressure on Iran over its fast-advancing nuclear program.\n\nWhile the election is unlikely to bring a major shift in the Islamic Republic's policies, its outcome could influence the succession to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's 85-year-old supreme leader, in power since 1989.\n\nThe clerical establishment sought a high turnout to offset a legitimacy crisis fueled by public discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom.\n\nThe next president is not expected to usher in any major policy shift on Iran's nuclear program or support for militia groups across the Middle East, since Khamenei calls all the shots on top state matters.\n\nHowever, the president runs the government day-to-day and can influence the tone of Iran's foreign and domestic policy.\n\nA hardline watchdog body, made up of six clerics and six jurists aligned with Khamenei, approved only six presidential candidates from an initial pool of 80. Two hardline candidates subsequently dropped out.\n\nLimited choices\n\nThree candidates are hardliners and one is a low-profile comparative moderate, backed by the reformist faction that has largely been sidelined in Iran in recent years.\n\nA source close to Pezeshkian had earlier told Reuters that 'so far, from the votes counted in small towns and villages, Pezeshkian is ahead of his rivals.'\n\nProminent among the remaining hardliners are Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf, parliament speaker and former commander of the powerful Revolutionary Guards, and Jalili, who served for four years in Khamenei's office.\n\nAn Iranian man votes at a polling station in Tehran, Iran, during a snap presidential election to choose a successor to Ebrahim Raisi following Raisi's death in a helicopter crash, June 28, 2024.\n\nCritics of Iran's clerical rule say that low turnouts in recent years show the system's legitimacy has eroded. Turnout was 48% in the 2021 presidential election and a record low of 41% in a parliamentary election in March.\n\n'Based on unconfirmed reports, the election is very likely heading to a second round. Based on the votes counted so far, Jalili and Pezeshkian will compete in a run-off election,' Tasnim reported.\n\nIf no candidate wins at least 50% plus one vote from all ballots cast, including blank votes, a run-off between the top two candidates is held on the first Friday after the result is declared.\n\nAll four candidates have vowed to revive the flagging economy, beset by mismanagement, state corruption and sanctions re-imposed since 2018, after the United States ditched Tehran's 2015 nuclear pact with six world powers.\n\n'I think Jalili is the only candidate who raised the issue of justice, fighting corruption and giving value to the poor. ... Most importantly, he does not link Iran's foreign policy to the nuclear deal,' said Farzan, a 45-year-old artist in the city of Karaj.\n\nDivided voters\n\nPezeshkian is faithful to Iran's theocratic rule, but advocates detente with the West, economic reform, social liberalization and political pluralism.\n\n'We will respect the hijab law, but there should never be any intrusive or inhumane behavior toward women,' Pezeshkian said after casting his vote.\n\nHe was referring to the death of Mahsa Amini, a young Kurdish woman, in 2022 while in morality police custody for allegedly violating the mandatory Islamic dress code.\n\nThe unrest sparked by Amini's death spiraled into the biggest show of opposition to Iran's clerical rulers in years.\n\nPezeshkian's chances hinge on reviving the enthusiasm of reform-minded voters who have largely stayed away from the polls for the last four years as a mostly youthful population chafes at political and social curbs. He could also benefit from his rivals' failure to consolidate the hardline vote.\n\n'I feel Pezeshkian represents both traditional and liberal thoughts,' said architect Pirouz, 45, who said he had planned to boycott the vote until he learned more about Pezeshkian's plans.\n\nIn the past few weeks, Iranians have made wide use of the hashtag #ElectionCircus on X, with some activists at home and abroad calling for a boycott, saying a high turnout would only serve to legitimize the Islamic Republic.\n\n'The youth were punished ... young girls were killed on the streets. ... We can't easily move on from that. ... After all that happened, it's unconscionable to vote,' said 55-year-old writer Shahrzad Afrasheh.\n\nIn the 2022-2023 protests, more than 500 people including 71 minors were killed, hundreds were injured and thousands arrested, rights groups said.", "source": {"uri": "northernirelandnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Northern Ireland News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
