UrduPoint", "body": "Tehran, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 29th Jun, 2024) Iran's sole reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian and ultraconservative Saeed Jalili are leading in snap presidential elections, according to early results on Saturday from the Interior Ministry.\n\nAccording to the latest count, Pezeshkian has won more than 8,300,000 votes and Jalili, a former nuclear negotiator, has over 7,100,000.\n\nThe Interior Ministry reported that more than 19,000,000 ballots had been counted so far.\n\nComing third in the early results is the conservative parliament speaker, Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, with about 2,600,000 votes.\n\nThe fourth, Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a conservative cleric, had 158,314 votes.\n\nThe Guardian Council, which vets electoral candidates in the Islamic republic, had originally approved six contenders.\n\nBut a day ahead of the election, two candidates -- the ultraconservative mayor of Tehran Alireza Zakani and Raisi's vice president Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi -- dropped out of the race.\n\nIn the 2021 elections that brought Raisi to power, the Council disqualified many reformists and moderates, prompting many voters to shun neck in Iran's presidential vote", "body": "A low-key moderate and a protege of Iran's supreme leader are neck and neck as votes are counted in snap presidential elections marked by voter apathy over economic hardship and social restrictions.\n\nWith more than 14 million ballots counted so far from Friday's polling, sole moderate candidate Masoud Pezeshkian has more 5.9 million votes and the hardline candidate, former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, more than 5.5 million, provisional results from the Interior Ministry showed.\n\nSome insiders said the turnout was about 40 per cent - a figure lower than expected by Iran's clerical rulers, while witnesses told Reuters that polling stations in Tehran and some other cities had not been crowded.\n\nIran's Tasnim news agency said a run-off election was \"very likely\" to pick the next president following the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nIf no candidate wins at least 50 per cent plus one vote from all ballots cast, including blank votes, a run-off between the top two candidates is held on the first Friday after the result is declared.\n\nThe election coincides with escalating regional tension due to the war between Israel and Iranian allies Hamas in Gaza and Hezbollah in Lebanon, as well as increased western pressure on Iran over its nuclear programme.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region - such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels - are engaged in fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, Iran continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build, should it choose to do so, several nuclear weapons.\n\nWhile the election is unlikely to bring a major shift in the Islamic Republic's policies, its outcome could influence the succession to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's 85-year-old supreme leader, in power since 1989.\n\nThe clerical establishment sought a high turnout to offset a legitimacy crisis fuelled by public discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom.\n\nThe next president is not expected to usher in any major policy shift on Iran's nuclear programme or support for militia groups across the Middle East, since Mr Khamenei decides top state matters.\n\nHowever, the president runs the government day-to-day and can influence the tone of Iran's foreign and domestic policy.\n\nMr Pezeshkian's views offer a contrast to those of Mr Jalili, advocating detente with the West, economic reform, social liberalisation and political pluralism.\n\nA staunch anti-westerner, a win by Mr Jalili would signal the possibility of an even more Pezeshikan collected 42.5% of the vote, and Jalili came in second place with 38.6%.\n\nThe election was prompted by the death of late President Ebrahim Raisi, who died on May 19 in a helicopter crash. Known as the \"butcher of Tehran,\" Ebrahim was responsible for executing hundreds of political prisoners during the 1980s before being elected president in 2021.\n\nWith the Iranian people jaded by the integrity of their democracy, this past election boasted the lowest turnout rates since the Islamic Republic was created in 1979. A total of 24 million voters cast their ballot, a 40% turnout.\n\nIn an effort to bolster Jalili's chances of winning, two conservative candidates dropped out days before Friday's election. Meanwhile, Pezeshkian was the only reformist candidate approved to run by the Guardian Council after it prevented dozens of contenders from appearing on the ballot.\n\nSina Toossi, an Iran analyst and senior fellow at the Center for International Policy in Washington, D.C., told CNN that Pezeshkian may have been permitted to run in the election only as a way of boosting voter turnout.\n\nCLICK HERE {"uri": "8201378382", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:25:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:25:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:23:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/iran-heading-runoff-election-neither-101539628.html", "title": "Iran heading for runoff election after neither lead candidate scores majority", "body": "Iran is heading to a runoff election in a week's time after the reformist lawmaker Masoud Pezeshkian secured a narrow lead over hardline former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili but failed to secure more than 50% of the votes.\n\nTurnout may end up low as 40%, a record low for an Iranian presidential election since the revolution in 1979.\n\nThe scale of the boycott is a rebuff for the regime, which had repeatedly urged Iranians to show their commitment to the Islamic regime by voting.\n\nRelated: Iran goes to polls to elect new president after Raisi killed in helicopter crash\n\nTurnout in the 2001 presidential election was officially recorded at 48.8% with 24.9 million voting.\n\nThe initial results showed Pezeshkian received 10.45m votes, Jalili 9.47m and the other leading conservative Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf 3.38m. A fourth candidate, Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a former justice minister who ran a wild card campaign, won only 206,000. A total of 24,735,185 people voted.\n\nAs the first vote tallies were announced, Pezeshkian was just behind Jalili, but he then overtook him and pushed ahead.\n\nA runoff on Friday seems inevitable and will offer a straight ideological choice between Pezeshkian and Jalili.\n\nUnless Pezeshkian can galvanise more voters to turn out, on the basis that the first round proved that he has a viable chance of winning and can change Iran, the reformist is likely to lose a runoff. The bulk, but not all, of the Ghalibaf votes are predicted to switch to Jalili. The rivalry between Ghalibaf and Jalili - both personal and ideological - was enough to prevent them reaching a pre-polling pact.\n\nThe snap election was called after the death of President Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash. In 2021, Raisi secured 18m votes, only 6m less than the total number of votes recorded as cast in 2024. Detailed comparisons showed that turnout was down in 2021 in almost all provinces except in Tehran and Qom.\n\nAbbas Akhoundi, a leading reformist, warned: \"About 60% of voters did not participate in the elections. Their message was clear. They object to the institutionalised discrimination in the existing governance and do not accept that they are second-class citizens and that a minority impose their will on the majority of Iranian society as first-class citizens.\n\n\"A large part of Iranian society does not see a place for itself in the ruling political institutions. Therefore, they had the right not to participate in the elections. The government should know that, if this procedure continues, this part of society will get bigger because even some of those who voted agree with this group.\"\n\nSix candidates, including five Conservatives, two of whom dropped out on the eve of the poll, were approved as qualified to stand by the Guardian Council, an unelected constitutional watchdog whose members are directly and indirectly appointed by supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\nThe decision to allow a reformist to stand was seen as a concession by the regime, which needed a more competitive election to try to lure voters to the polls.\n\nIran needs leaders with legitimacy as it supports resistance movements across the Middle East, confronts unelected Gulf monarchies and challenges the west over the purpose and scale of its currently expanding nuclear programme.\n\nRelated: US imposes fresh sanctions on Iran over apparent nuclear escalations\n\nOn Friday, the UN nuclear watchdog reported Tehran had installed four of eight new centrifuges at its Fordow facilities, speeding its uranium enrichment facilities.\n\nThe reformist movement that stretches back many decades inside Iran was divided over whether to participate, with many leading figures including political prisoners, such as the Nobel prize winner Narges Mohammadi, calling for a boycott.\n\nOther jailed thinkers on the left such as Majid Tavakoli urged voters from behind bars not to vote.\n\nJudging by the makeup of the sometimes large crowds at Pezeshkian's rallies, the reformists seem to have failed to persuade the younger generation demanding greater cultural freedom that their movement, or the route of the ballot box, offers real change. Some describe Gen Z Iran as depoliticised, and others simply conscious that elected politicians in Iran do not have controls over the levers of power that remain with the supreme leader, and the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.\n\nPezeshkian has used video town hall meetings to engage with students and promised no crackdown on those that refuse to wear the hijab. But at the heart of his campaign has been a call that the country's economic travails will not end unless it engages with western economies, including through renegotiating the Iranian nuclear deal. Actively supported by the former foreign minister Javad Zarif, he has accused hardliners of taking Iran down an ideological, cultural and economic cul-de-sac.\n\nThe big question now will be whether those around the supreme leader will hold an honest discussion about the turnout and self-evident alienation of Iranians.\n\nOne Tehran citizen, Kianoosh Sanjari, struck by the contrast between the official TV reports of excitement at the polls and what he had seen on the streets of the capital, travelled to 14 polling booths, and did not find more than five people queueing to vote. He said he then went to Laleh (Tulip) Park, one of his favourite haunts in Tehran, and found old men playing chess under a gazebo, crowds of youngsters playing badminton football and volleyball, and children practising slacklining.\n\n\"I don't know about the situation in other cities, but I can definitely say that the absolute majority of people in Tehran ignored the presidential appointments of the Islamic Republic of Iran and did not participate in them.\"\n\nHe added: \"All the domestic media of Iran served to heat up the oven of this election. Both sides were given a chance to speak their hearts out (and not to someone like me). Both factions sent text messages to the people. They conveyed their message to the people in all social networks.\n\n\"Call it discouragement, despair, indifference or collective consciousness.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8201336207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:45:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:45:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:45:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/nation-world/iran-goes-to-a-runoff-election-between-reformist-pezeshkian-and-hard-liner-jalili/article_6ca5fafc-35f7-11ef-81dc-1f86c546d88c.html", "title": "Iran goes to a runoff election between reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Iran will hold a runoff presidential election to replace the late hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi, an official said Saturday, after an initial vote saw the top candidates not securing an outright win in the lowest turnout poll ever held in the Islamic Republic by percentage.\n\nThe election this coming Friday will pit reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian against the hard-line former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili.\n\nMohsen Eslami, an election spokesman, announced the result in a news conference carried by Iranian state television. He said of 24.5 million votes cast, Pezeshkian got 10.4 million while Jalili received 9.4 million. Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf got 3.3 million. Shiite cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi had over 206,000 votes.\n\nIranian law requires that a winner gets more than 50% of all votes cast. If not, the race's top two candidates will advance to a runoff a week later. There's been only one runoff presidential election in Iran's history: in 2005, when hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad bested former President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.\n\nJanet Jackson, with Nelly opener, mostly wows crowd at Hollywood Casino Amphitheatre Acclaimed St. Louis restaurant Bulrush closes. Owner cites 'hate politics' in Missouri. Column: Janet Jackson surprises St. Louis dance class, and I was there Ramsay's Kitchen by Gordon Ramsay is worse than bad. It's boring. Call for 'militia' at Ascension Catholic Church in Chesterfield was a mistake, pastor says Missouri governor declares emergency as Missouri River swells Work stops at Chesterfield music production facility after clash between builder, owner Boeing moves forward with 'advanced combat aircraft' site in St. Louis County Six people shot, one killed in downtown St. Louis Plan to remake St. Louis riverfront, Midtown hotel project move ahead with tax breaks BenFred: Cardinals shortstop Masyn Winn looks like a rising star the Braves would try to extend Baby bear spotted in Ballwin neighborhood Cicadas have laid eggs in the St. Louis region, killing tree branch tips in the process St. Charles County developer can move forward with controversial 120-home project St. Louis archdiocese releases long-awaited report on Catholic slaveholding\n\nEslami acknowledged the country's Guardian Council would need to offer formal approval, but the result did not draw any immediate challenge from contenders in the race.\n\nAs has been the case since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, women and those calling for radical change have been barred from running, while the vote itself will have no oversight from internationally recognized monitors.\n\nThere were signs of the wider disenchantment of the public with the vote. More than 1 million votes were voided, according to the results, typically a sign of people feeling obligated to cast a ballot but not wanting to select any of the candidates.\n\nThe overall turnout was 39.9%, according to the results. The 2021 presidential election that elected Raisi saw a 42% turnout, while the March parliamentary election saw a 41% turnout.\n\nThere had been calls for a boycott, including from imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi. Mir Hossein Mousavi, one of the leaders of the 2009 Green Movement protests who remains under house arrest, has also refused to vote along with his wife, his daughter said.\n\nThere's also been criticism that Pezeshkian represents just another government-approved candidate. In a documentary on the reformist candidate aired by state TV, one woman said her generation was \"moving toward the same level\" of animosity with the government that Pezeshkian's generation had in the 1979 revolution.\n\nRaisi, 63, died in the May 19 helicopter crash that also killed the country's foreign minister and others. He was seen as a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and a potential successor. Still, many knew him for his involvement in the mass executions that Iran conducted in 1988, and for his role in the bloody crackdowns on dissent that followed protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, a young woman detained by police over allegedly improperly wearing the mandatory headscarf, or hijab.\n\nThe voting came as wider tensions have gripped the Middle East over the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nIn April, Iran launched its first-ever direct attack on Israel over the war in Gaza, while militia groups that Tehran arms in the region -- such as the Lebanese Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels -- are engaged in the fighting and have escalated their attacks.\n\nMeanwhile, the Islamic Republic continues to enrich uranium at near weapons-grade levels and maintains a stockpile large enough to build -- should it choose to do so -- several nuclear weapons.\n\nDespite the recent unrest, there was only one reported attack around the election. Gunmen opened fire on a van transporting ballot boxes in the restive southeastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan, killing two police officers and wounding others, the state-run IRNA news agency reported. The province regularly sees violence between security forces and the militant group Jaish al-Adl, as well as drug traffickers.\n\nVahdat reported from Tehran, Iran. Nasser Karimi in Tehran, Iran, contributed to this report.\n\n0 Comments", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8201816095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "17:39:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T17:39:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T17:36:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/amid-record-low-vote-turnout-iran-set-for-presidential-run-off-on-july-5/2153577/", "title": "Amid record low vote turnout, Iran set for presidential run-off on July 5", "body": "According to the Ministry of Interior, just 40 per cent of more than 61 million eligible Iranians voted, setting a new low in presidential elections since the country's 1979 revolution.\n\nThe final data from election headquarters at the ministry revealed that Pezeshkian won more than 10.41 million votes from a total of more than 24.5 million ballots tabulated, trailing former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili by 9.47 million votes. Only the second time since the 1979 revolution has a presidential election been held, reported Al Jazeera.\n\nMohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, the Conservative Speaker of the Parliament secured 3.38 million votes, and conservative Islamic leader Mostafa Pourmohammadi, got 206,397 votes and was therefore knocked out of the race. Two other candidates, Tehran Mayor Alireza Zakani and government official Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh Hashemi, dropped out.\n\nMeanwhile, Ghalibaf, Zakani, and Ghazizadeh called on their supporters to vote for Jalili in the run-off next Friday to ensure victory for the \"revolution front\".\n\nThe snap election on Friday occurred inside the 50-day legally mandated deadline for selecting a new president after Ebrahim Raisi and seven others, including Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian, were killed in a helicopter accident on May 19.\n\nThe vote on Friday witnessed a low turnout, as has been the case in all key elections over the last four years, but the final figure was far lower than the 45-53 percent predicted by surveys. Raisi was elected with the lowest presidential turnout in Iran's more than four-decade history, at 48.8 per cent, reported Al Jazeera.\n\nThe parliamentary election in March and May had the lowest turnout of any major poll since Iran's 1979 revolution, at slightly less than 41 per cent.\n\nJalili, a senior member of the Supreme National Security Council, has pledged to reduce inflation to single digits and improve economic growth to an impressive 8 per cent, while also combating corruption and incompetence. He recommends taking a stronger stance against the West and its supporters.\n\nPezeshkian was the only moderate among six persons authorized to run by the Guardian Council, the constitutional authority that examines all candidates. His supporters have portrayed him not as a miracle worker, but as a potential president who might make things somewhat better while maintaining that a victory for Jalili would signify a big setback.\n\nHowever, it is important to note that Jalili's name is associated with years-long nuclear discussions in the late 2000s and early 2010s, which finally led to Iran's isolation on the global stage. {"uri": "8201182061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "07:25:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T07:25:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T07:24:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/khameneis-protege-jalili-edges-ahead-in-tight-iran-presidential-race/2152817/", "title": "Khamenei's protege Jalili edges ahead in tight Iran presidential race", "body": "Some insiders said the turnout was around 40%, lower than expected by Iran's clerical rulers, while witnesses told Reuters that polling stations in Tehran and some other cities were not crowded.\n\nIran's Tasnim news agency said a run-off election was \"very likely\" to pick the next president following the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash.\n\nThe election coincides with escalating regional tension due to the war between Israel and Iranian allies Hamas in Gaza and Hezbollah in Lebanon, as well as increased Western pressure on Iran over its fast-advancing nuclear programme.\n\nWhile the election is unlikely to bring a major shift in the Islamic Republic's policies, its outcome could influence the succession to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's 85-year-old supreme leader, in power since 1989.\n\nThe clerical establishment sought a high turnout to offset a legitimacy crisis fuelled by public discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom.\n\nThe next president is not expected to usher in any major policy shift on Iran's nuclear programme or support for militia groups across the Middle East, since Khamenei calls all the shots on top state matters.\n\nHowever, the president runs the government day-to-day and can influence the tone of Iran's foreign and domestic policy.\n\nJalili, a former diplomat, describes himself as a pious believer in \"velayat-e faqih\", or rule by supreme jurisprudence, Iran's system of Islamic government that provides the basis for Khamenei's paramount position.\n\nIran's presidential election is a contest among a tightly controlled group of three hardline candidates and one low-profile moderate loyal to the supreme leader.\n\nA hardline watchdog body approved only six from an initial pool of 80 and two hardline candidates subsequently dropped out.\n\nPezeshkian is backed by the reformist camp that has been largely sidelined in Iran in recent years.\n\nCritics of Iran's clerical rule say that low turnouts in recent years show the system's legitimacy has eroded. Turnout was 48% in the 2021 presidential election and a record low of 41% of people voted in a parliamentary election in March.\n\n\"Based on unconfirmed reports, the election is very likely heading to a second round ... Jalili and Pezeshkian will compete in a run-off election,\" Tasnim reported.\n\nIf no candidate wins at least 50% plus one vote from all ballots cast, including blank votes, a run-off between the top two candidates is held on the first Friday after the result is declared.\n\nAll candidates have vowed to revive the flagging economy, beset by mismanagement, state corruption and sanctions re-imposed since 2018, after the United States ditched Tehran's 2015 nuclear pact with six world powers.\n\n\"I think Jalili is the only candidate who raised the issue of justice, fighting corruption and giving value to the poor. ... Most importantly, he does not link Iran's foreign policy to the nuclear deal,\" said Farzan, a 45-year-old artist in the city of Karaj.\n\nPezeshkian is faithful to Iran's theocratic rule, but advocates detente with the West, economic reform, social liberalisation and political pluralism.\n\n\"We will respect the hijab law, but there should never be any intrusive or inhumane behaviour toward women,\" Pezeshkian said after casting his vote.\n\nHe was referring to the death of Mahsa Amini, a young Kurdish woman, in 2022 while in morality police custody for allegedly violating the mandatory Islamic dress code.\n\nThe unrest sparked by Amini's death spiralled into the biggest show of opposition to Iran's clerical rulers in years.\n\nPezeshkian attempted to revive the enthusiasm of reform-minded voters who have largely stayed away from the polls for the last four years as a mostly youthful population chafes at political and social curbs. He could also benefit from his rivals' failure to consolidate the hardline vote.\n\n\"I feel Pezeshkian represents both traditional and liberal thoughts,\" said architect Pirouz, 45, who said he had planned to boycott the vote until he learned more about Pezeshkian's plans.\n\nIn the past few weeks, Iranians have made wide use of the hashtag #ElectionCircus on X, with some activists at home and abroad calling for a boycott, saying a high turnout would only serve to legitimise the Islamic Republic.\n\n\"The youth were punished ... young girls were killed on the streets ... We can't easily move on from that. ... After all that happened, it's unconscionable to vote,\" said 55-year-old writer Shahrzad Afrasheh.\n\nIn the 2022/23 protests, more than 500 people including 71 minors were killed, hundreds were injured and thousands arrested, rights groups said.\n\n(Additional reporting by Elwely Elwelly; Writing by Parisa Hafezi; Editing by Peter Graff, Clarence Fernandez, Alex Richardson, Kevin Liffey, Leslie Adler, Diane Craft and Himani Sarkar)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@theprint.in", "name": "Reuters", "type": {"uri": "8196192118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-26", "time": "09:54:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-26T09:54:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-26T09:53:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1842094", "title": "Iran to pick new president at turbulent time", "body": "Among the six candidates is lone reformist Massoud Pezeshkian who hopes he can challenge the dominance of conservatives in the Islamic republic.\n\nIranians will vote on Friday to elect a new president from six candidates, including a lone reformist who hopes he can challenge the dominance of conservatives in the Islamic republic.\n\nA presidential election had not been due until 2025, but was brought forward after ultraconservative Ebrahim Raisi died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe snap poll comes at a challenging time as Iran grapples with the economic impact of international sanctions amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza conflict between Israel and Tehran's ally Hamas.\n\nIn April, Iran fired more than 300 missiles and drones at Israel after an air strike in Damascus blamed on Israel killed seven Revolutionary Guards. Israel carried out a reported retaliatory strike near Isfahan.\n\nPolling is also being held just five months before a presidential election in the United States, Iran's sworn enemy and Israel's staunch ally.\n\nLeading contenders for Iran's second highest-ranking office are conservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, and the sole reformist, Massoud Pezeshkian.\n\nThe others are conservative Tehran mayor Alireza Zakani, cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, and incumbent vice president Amirhossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi, the ultraconservative head of the Martyrs' Foundation.\n\nThe six have staged largely low-key campaigns, which included televised debates where they vowed to tackle economic challenges and offered varied views on Iran's relations with the West.\n\nAli Vaez of the International Crisis Group says the new president will also have to tackle the challenge of the deepening \"fissure between the state and society\".\n\n\"Nobody has presented a concrete plan of how they are going to deal with a lot of these issues,\" he said.\n\nSupreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who wields the ultimate authority in Iran, urged \"high participation\" on Friday.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, voters shunned the polls after many reformists and moderates were disqualified.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 per cent -- the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nPeople appear divided over whether voting will mean any key concerns being addressed. These include the mounting effects of soaring inflation and the decline of the rial against the dollar.\n\n\"There's no way I'm voting,\" said Neda, an engineer who gave only her first name, in northern Tehran.\n\n\"No matter who takes the post, none of them is sympathetic with the nation. My vote won't affect anything,\" she told AFP.\n\nIn contrast, 60-year-old housewife Jaleh said she was rooting for reformist Pezeshkian, who comes \"from the people\" and could address unemployment and poverty.\n\nReformist figures including former president Mohammad Khatami and ex-foreign minister Mohammad Javad Zarif have endorsed Pezeshkian.\n\nHowever, some Iranians view the 69-year-old reformist as lacking government experience -- he only served as health minister about 20 years ago.\n\nOf the main contenders, Ghalibaf is a veteran politician and former member of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, ideological defenders of the republic after the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, an ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator known for his inflexible stance towards the West, seems to be attracting hardline support.\n\nAlireza Valadkhani, a 35-year-old tax consultant, told AFP that he will vote for Ghalibaf as he \"is the only one who can help Iran in its current situation\".\n\nOne concern among voters is whether a new president will mean a potential change to the contentious hijab law for women, particularly since the mass protests triggered by the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, was detained for allegedly breaching Iran's dress code which makes women cover their heads and necks and wear modest clothing in public.\n\nSince the protests, women have increasingly flouted the code. But police have toughened controls in recent months on those who ignore the rules.\n\nMost of the candidates have been cautious in the televised debates, saying they generally opposed the use of violence against those who do not wear the mandatory headscarf.\n\n\"For 40 years, we have sought to fix the hijab, but we made the situation worse,\" Pezeshkian said in campaigning. For many women, the idea of a change to the hijab laws seems far-fetched.\n\n\"It is hard for the candidates to fulfil their promises\" on this, said 31-year-old Maryam, who also gave only her first name.\n\nNeda said: \"The hijab law will never be lifted since this is the Islamic republic. \"I don't think any president would be willing to change this law. \"", "source": {"uri": "dawn.com", presidential election amounted to 40 percent.\n\nThe official added that the final result must be approved by the Guardian Council of Iran.\n\n\"Therefore, since none of the candidates received 50 "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://gulfnews.com/world/mena/who-are-the-candidates-in-irans-presidential-election-1.103303491", "title": "Who are the candidates in Iran's presidential election?", "body": "TEHRAN: Six candidates -- five conservatives and one reformist -- are competing in Iran's presidential election on Friday to succeed the late Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nHere is a look at the candidate list: Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf\n\nGet exclusive content with Gulf News WhatsApp channel\n\nGhalibaf, 62, is a prominent conservative who has served as parliament speaker since 2020.\n\nBorn on September 23, 1961 near the northeastern city of Mashhad, he has held various governmental roles including mayor of Tehran.\n\nAlso read Iran elections 2024: For youth, legacy of 2022 clashes shapes presidential race Iran opens registration for presidential candidates EU, France see no better deal for Iran Iran nuclear deal 'in ER room' -- Israeli defence minister\n\nGhalibaf has run for the presidency three times - 2005, 2013 and 2017, the last of which he withdrew from to support Raisi's candidacy.\n\nBefore entering politics, he was in the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, the ideological defenders of the Islamic republic.\n\nSupreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei appointed him as head of the Guards' air force in 1997, and he became the head of the police force in 2000.\n\nAmir-Hossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi\n\nGhazizadeh-Hashemi, 53, is an ultraconservative medical doctor and a staunch supporter of Raisi's government.\n\nBorn on April 14, 1971, he serves as vice-president and heads the Martyrs' Foundation.\n\nPreviously, he represented Mashhad in parliament for four consecutive terms.\n\nIn the 2021 presidential election, he secured 3.5 percent of the vote.\n\nSaeed Jalili\n\nJalili, 58, is an ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator known for his uncompromising anti-West stance.\n\nBorn on September 6, 1965 in Mashhad, he was selected by Khamenei as one of his representatives in Iran's Supreme National Security Council.\n\nA veteran of the Iran-Iraq war, Jalili lost a foot during his service.\n\nHe led Iran's nuclear programme negotiations between 2007 and 2013 and strongly opposed the 2015 nuclear deal with the United States and Western governments, which aimed to curb Tehran's nuclear activity in return for sanctions relief.\n\nJalili ran for president in 2013 and supported Raisi in 2017, withdrawing his candidacy.\n\nMassoud Pezeshkian\n\nPezeshkian, 69, is the oldest candidate and the sole reformist in the race.\n\nBorn on September 29, 1954, he is an outspoken heart surgeon who has represented the northwestern city of Tabriz in parliament since 2008.\n\nHe was health minister in the government of former reformist president Mohammad Khatami.\n\nIn the 2021 presidential race that brought Raisi to power, he was disqualified alongside other reformist and moderate candidates.\n\nRecently, he criticised Raisi's government for lacking transparency during nationwide protests triggered by the September 2022 death in police custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nMostafa Pourmohammadi\n\nPourmohammadi, 64, is the only cleric in Iran's presidential elections.\n\nA conservative and a veteran politician, he was born on December 23, 1959 in the religious city of Qom.\n\nHe held multiple positions over his career including in Iran's intelligence ministry.\n\nPourmohammadi took the post of interior minister under the government of hardline president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, and served as justice minister under moderate president Hassan Rouhani.\n\nAlireza ZakaniZakani, 58, is an ultraconservative who has served as Tehran's mayor since August 2021.\n\nBorn in the capital on April 2, 1965, he is a veteran of the Iran-Iraq war.\n\nZakani was a candidate in the 2021 presidential election before withdrawing to support Raisi. He was disqualified from running in 2013 and 2017.\n\nHe was a lawmaker for four separate terms, representing Tehran for three terms and Qom for one.\n\nHe was a staunch critic of the 2015 nuclear {"uri": "8201506902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:24:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:24:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T12:22:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/khamenei-protege-sole-moderate-to-battle-in-irans-presidential-run-off/2153193/", "title": "Khamenei protege, sole moderate to battle in Iran's presidential run-off", "body": "The interior ministry said neither secured the 50% plus one vote of over 25 million ballots cast required to win outright, with Pezeshkian leading with over 10 million votes ahead of Jalili with over 9.4 million votes.\n\nPower in Iran ultimately lies with Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, so the result will not herald any major policy shift on Iran's nuclear programme or its support for militia groups across the Middle East.\n\nBut the president runs the government day-to-day and can influence the tone of Iran's policy.\n\nThe clerical establishment hoped for a high turnout as it faces a legitimacy crisis fuelled by public discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom. However, turnout in Friday's vote hit a historic low of about 40%, based on interior ministry count released on Saturday.\n\nThe election comes at a time of escalating regional tension due to the war between Israel and Iranian allies Hamas in Gaza and Hezbollah in Lebanon, as well as increased Western pressure on Iran over its fast-advancing nuclear programme.\n\nWith Iran's supreme leader now 85, it is likely that the next president will be closely involved in the process of choosing a successor to Khamenei, who seeks a fiercely loyal president who can ensure a smooth eventual succession to his own position, insiders and analysts say.\n\nAnti-Western views of Jalili, Iran's former uncompromising nuclear negotiator, offer a contrast to those of Pezeshkian. Analysts said Jalili's win would signal the possibility of an even more antagonistic turn in the Islamic Republic's foreign and domestic policy.\n\nBut a victory for mild-mannered lawmaker Pezeshkian might help ease tensions with the West, improve chances of economic reform, social liberalisation and political pluralism.\n\nPezeshkian, faithful to Iran's theocratic rule, is backed by the reformist faction that has largely been sidelined in Iran in recent years.\n\n\"We will respect the hijab law, but there should never be any intrusive or inhumane behaviour toward women,\" Pezeshkian said after casting his vote.\n\nHe was referring to the death of Mahsa Amini, a young Kurdish woman, in 2022 while in morality police custody for allegedly violating the mandatory Islamic dress code.\n\nThe unrest sparked by Amini's death spiralled into the biggest show of opposition to Iran's clerical rulers in years.\n\n(Writing by Parisa HafeziEditing by Tomasz Janowski)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201120749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "06:23:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T06:23:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T06:23:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://eaworldview.com/2024/06/iran-election-reformist-pezeshkian-hardliner-jalili-lead/", "title": "Iran (Mis-Managed?) Election: Reformist Pezeshkian, Hardliner Jalili Lead - EA WorldView", "body": "In a surprise development, reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hardliner Saeed Jalili are leading in the first round of Iran's President election.\n\nPezeshkian, an MP and former Health Minister has 5,955,781 votes. Jalili, best known as Iran's lead nuclear negotiator and Secretary of the National Security Council, has 5,560,321.\n\nConservative Parliament Speaker Mohammad-Bagher Ghalibaf is a distant third with 1,891,385 votes. Conservative former Interior Minister Mostafa Pourmohammadi has 111,967.\n\nThe top two candidates proceed to a run-off, unless one has a majority of all valid votes.\n\nSee also A Beginner's Guide to Iran's \"Managed\" Presidential Election\n\nPezeshkian initially appeared to be a token reformist candidate -- all others were blocked by the Guardian Council, which carries out vetting on behalf of Iran's leadership -- in the hope of boosting voter turnout past the historic lows in recent elections.\n\nThe leadership appeared to judge that Pezeshkian would not have the charisma and policies to mobilize mass support. However, the Council may have miscalculated, with centrists and reformists able to rally around a single figure.\n\nOther analysts believe that a strong first-round performance by Pezeshkian is acceptable to the regime, since he would lose to its preferred candidate in the run-off. And there are some who argue that Pezeshkian has curbed his views -- for example, silence on the strict house arrests of opposition leaders Mir Hossein Mousavi, Mehdi Karroubi, and Zahra Rahnavard since February 2011 -- so he has a chance of victory.\n\nThe other surprise so far is the poor performance of Ghalibaf, a high-profile candidate -- this is his fourth run for the Presidency -- who was close with Pezeshkian and Jalili in polling.\n\nEarlier this week, some regime figures called for hardliners and conservatives to rally around a single candidate, apparently from concern about Pezeshkian's unexpected strength in polling.\n\nOne hardline and one conservative dropped out. However, both Ghalibaf and Jalili refused to step aside.\n\nAlmost 15 million ballots have been counted so far -- about 25% of the 61 million Iranians eligible to vote.\n\nIn 2021, official turnout of 48.5%, an all-time low since the Islamic Republic was established in 1979. Earlier this year, Parliamentary elections officially recorded 42% participation.\n\nThe election was called after the death last month of hardline President Ebrahim Raisi, whom the Supreme Leader hailed as his \"servant\", in a helicopter crash as he was returning from Azerbaijan.\n\nIn 2009, Green Movement leader Mousavi, promising reform, appeared to lead the first round amid a surge of enthusiasm across Iran. However, the regime proclaimed that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad had \"won\" with 63% of the vote.\n\nMore than a million Iranians took to the streets, calling for a fair election, rights, and reforms. The protests were eventually repressed by regime forces, with widespread detentions, scores of demonstrators slain, and the house arrests of Mousavi, fellow candidate Karroubi, and Mousavi's wife, academic, and activist Rahnavard.\n\nFour years later, the Council disqualified former President Hashemi Rafsanjani, in an attempt to stem centrists and reformists. However, it allowed a consolation candidate, Rafsanjani's prot\u00e9g\u00e9 Hassan Rouhani.\n\nThe tactic backfired when Rouhani won a first-round victory, and the Supreme Leader -- probably mindful of 2009 -- decided not to intervene. Rouhani served two terms, and was succeeded by Raisi in 2021.", "source": {"uri": "eaworldview.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "EA WorldView"}, "authors": [{"uri": "scott_lucas@eaworldview.com", and neck in Iran presidential race", "body": "A low-key moderate and a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran's supreme leader are neck-and-neck in the vote count in snap presidential elections marked by voter apathy over economic hardships and social restrictions.\n\nMore than 14 million votes have been counted so far from Friday's vote, of which the sole moderate candidate Massoud Pezeshkian had won over 5.9 million votes and his hardline challenger former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili over 5.5 million, provisional results by the interior ministry showed.\n\nSome insiders said the turnout was around 40%, lower than expected by Iran's clerical rulers, while witnesses told Reuters that polling stations in Tehran and some other cities were not crowded.\n\nIran's Tasnim news agency said a run-off election was \"very likely\" to pick the next president following the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nIf no candidate wins at least 50% plus one vote from all ballots cast, including blank votes, a run-off between the top two candidates is held on the first Friday after the result is declared.\n\nThe election coincides with escalating regional tension due to the war between Israel and Iranian allies Hamas in Gaza and Hezbollah in Lebanon, as well as increased Western pressure on Iran over its fast-advancing nuclear program.\n\nWhile the election is unlikely to bring a major shift in the Islamic Republic's policies, its outcome could influence the succession to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's 85-year-old supreme leader, in power since 1989.\n\nThe clerical establishment sought a high turnout to offset a legitimacy crisis fuelled by public discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom.\n\nThe next president is not expected {"uri": "2024-06-402474520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-26", "time": "15:11:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-26T15:11:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-26T15:01:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://thestreetjournal.org/iran-to-elect-new-president-on-friday-weeks-after-death-of-raisi/", "title": "Iran to elect new president on Friday, weeks after death of Raisi", "body": "Ado Bayero now a private citizen - Gov Yusuf declares over deposed Kano Emir\n\nIranians will vote on Friday, June 28 to elect a new president from six candidates, including a lone reformist who aims to challenge the dominance of conservatives in the Islamic republic.\n\nOriginally scheduled for 2025, the presidential election was moved up following the death of ultraconservative Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe sudden poll takes place amidst economic challenges caused by international sanctions, as well as heightened regional tensions due to the Gaza conflict involving Israel and Tehran's ally Hamas.\n\nIn April, Iran launched more than 300 missiles and drones at Israel in response to an airstrike in Damascus that killed seven Revolutionary Guards, an incident blamed on Israel.\n\nIsrael reportedly retaliated with a strike near Isfahan.\n\nThe polling coincides with a presidential election in the United States, Iran's sworn enemy and Israel's staunch ally, just five months away.\n\nLeading contenders for Iran's second-highest office include conservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili and the sole reformist, Massoud Pezeshkian.\n\nThe remaining candidates are conservative Tehran mayor Alireza Zakani, cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi and incumbent vice president Amirhossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi, who heads the ultraconservative Martyrs' Foundation.\n\nThese six candidates have conducted relatively subdued campaigns, featuring televised debates where they pledged to address economic difficulties and presented diverse perspectives on Iran's relations with the West.\n\nAccording to Ali Vaez from the International Crisis Group, the incoming president will also confront the task of addressing the widening divide between the state and society.\n\n\"Nobody has presented a concrete plan of how they are going to deal with a lot of these issues,\" he said.\n\nSupreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who holds the ultimate authority in Iran, called for high participation on Friday, June 28.\n\nDuring the 2021 election that saw Raisi elected, voter turnout was low as many reformist and moderate candidates were disqualified from running.\n\nThe turnout at that time was just under 49 percent, marking the lowest in any presidential election in Iran's history.\n\nThere seems to be a division among people on whether voting will address their key concerns, such as the rising impact of inflation and the depreciation of the rial against dollar.\n\n\"There's no way I'm voting,\" said Neda, an engineer who preferred to use only her first name in northern Tehran.\n\n\"No matter who takes the post, none of them is sympathetic with the nation. My vote won't affect anything,\" she said.\n\nIn contrast, 60 years old housewife Jaleh expressed her support for reformist Pezeshkian, noting his grassroots connection and potential to tackle unemployment and poverty.\n\nReformist leaders, including former president Mohammad Khatami and ex-foreign minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, have endorsed Pezeshkian.\n\nHowever, some Iranians are concerned about the 69 years old reformist's limited government experience, noting that he served only briefly as health minister around 20 years ago.\n\nThe main contenders, Ghalibaf is a veteran politician and former member of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, ideological defenders of the republic after the 1979 revolution.\n\nJalili, an ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator known for his unwavering stance towards the West, appears to be attracting hardline support.\n\nAlireza Valadkhani, 35 years old tax consultant, stated he will vote for Ghalibaf because he believes Ghalibaf is the most capable candidate to assist Iran in its current situation.\n\nOne concern among voters is whether the new president will bring about a potential change to Iran's contentious hijab law for women.\n\nThis issue has gained prominence, especially following mass protests sparked by the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini, a 22 years old Iranian Kurd.\n\nAmini was detained for allegedly violating Iran's dress code, which requires women to cover their heads, necks and wear modest clothing in public.\n\nSince the protests, more women have been openly defying these regulations.\n\nNevertheless, police enforcement against rule-breakers has strengthened in recent months.\n\nIn televised debates, most candidates have been careful with their words, typically voicing disapproval of violence against individuals who choose not to wear the mandatory headscarf.\n\n\"For 40 years, we have sought to fix the hijab, but we made the situation worse,\" Pezeshkian said in campaigning.\n\nMany women find the notion of a change to the hijab laws unlikely.\n\n\"It is hard for the candidates to fulfil their promises on this,\" said 31 years old Maryam, who also gave only her first name.\n\nNeda said, \"The hijab law will never be lifted since this is the Islamic republic.\n\n\"I don't think any president would be willing to change this law.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201308283", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:20:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:20:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:20:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/29/world/middleeast/iran-election-masoud-pezeshkian-saeed-jalili.html", "title": "Reformist Reaches Runoff in Iran's Presidential Election", "body": "Candidates in the campaign to fill the seat of President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash, showed notable candor about the country's mounting problems.\n\nA reformist candidate critical of an Iranian law that requires women to wear head scarves will compete next week against a hard-line conservative in a runoff election for the country's presidency, state media said on Saturday, following a special vote after the previous leader was killed last month in a helicopter crash.\n\nA second round of voting, which will pit the reformist, Masoud Pezeshkian, against Saeed Jalili, an ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator, will take place on July 5. The runoff was in part the result of low voter turnout and a crowded field of four candidates, three of whom competed for the conservative vote. Iranian law requires a winner to receive more than 50 percent of all votes cast.\n\nParticipation in another round of voting will strain the energies of an already apathetic electorate, unsatisfied by their leaders at a time of international and domestic turmoil. Iran's economy is cratering under punishing Western sanctions, its citizens' freedoms are increasingly curtailed and its foreign policy is largely shaped by hard-line leaders.\n\nThe campaign, which initially included six candidates -- five conservatives and one reformist -- was notable for how candidly those issues were discussed and a public willingness to attack the status quo. In speeches, televised debates and round-table discussions, the candidates criticized government policies and ridiculed rosy official assessments of Iran's economic prospects as harmful delusions.\n\nPublic dissatisfaction in any new president's ability to bring change was reflected in low turnout for the election: According to Iran's state news agency, only 40 percent of eligible voters cast ballots.\n\nIn the official results announced on Saturday, Dr. Pezeshkian led with 10.4 million votes (42.4 percent), followed by Mr. Jalili at 9.4 million (38.6 percent). A third conservative candidate, Gen. Mohammad Baqer Ghalibaf, the current speaker of Parliament and former mayor of Tehran, was a distant third at 3.3 million (13.8 percent).", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", 29 (Xinhua) -- Iran's 14th presidential election on Saturday entered a runoff vote, with former Health Minister Masoud Pezeshkian and former chief nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili leading in the first round but no one gets minimum threshold of 50 percent of votes, Iran's Election Headquarters Spokesperson Mohsen Eslami said.\n\nThe spokesperson said turnout of the voting stands at 40 percent, 9,473,298, or over 38 percent.\n\nParliament Speaker Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf got 3,383,340, or 13.8 percent, and Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a former interior minister and justice minister, got 206,397, or {"uri": "2024-06-405678475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:18:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:18:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:15:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/29/iran-heading-for-runoff-election-after-neither-lead-candidate-scores-majority", "title": "Iran heading for runoff election after neither lead candidate scores majority", "body": "Turnout estimated to be as low as 40%, a record low since the revolution and a rebuff for the regime\n\nIran is heading to a runoff election in a week's time after the reformist lawmaker Masoud Pezeshkian secured a narrow lead over hardline former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili but failed to secure more than 50% of the votes.\n\nTurnout may end up low as 40%, a record low for an Iranian presidential election since the revolution in 1979.\n\nThe scale of the boycott is a rebuff for the regime, which had repeatedly urged Iranians to show their commitment to the Islamic regime by voting.\n\nTurnout in the 2001 presidential election was officially recorded at 48.8% with 24.9 million voting.\n\nThe initial results showed Pezeshkian received 10.45m votes, Jalili 9.47m and the other leading conservative Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf 3.38m. A fourth candidate, Mostafa Pourmohammadi, a former justice minister who ran a wild card campaign, won only 206,000. A total of 24,735,185 people voted.\n\nAs the first vote tallies were announced, Pezeshkian was just behind Jalili, but he then overtook him and pushed ahead.\n\nA runoff on Friday seems inevitable and will offer a straight ideological choice between Pezeshkian and Jalili.\n\nUnless Pezeshkian can galvanise more voters to turn out, on the basis that the first round proved that he has a viable chance of winning and can change Iran, the reformist is likely to lose a runoff. The bulk, but not all, of the Ghalibaf votes are predicted to switch to Jalili. The rivalry between Ghalibaf and Jalili - both personal and ideological - was enough to prevent them reaching a pre-polling pact.\n\nThe snap election was called after the death of President Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash. In 2021, Raisi secured 18m votes, only 6m less than the total number of votes recorded as cast in 2024. Detailed comparisons showed that turnout was down in 2021 in almost all provinces except in Tehran and Qom.\n\nAbbas Akhoundi, a leading reformist, warned: \"About 60% of voters did not participate in the elections. Their message was clear. They object to the institutionalised discrimination in the existing governance and do not accept that they are second-class citizens and that a minority impose their will on the majority of Iranian society as first-class citizens.\n\n\"A large part of Iranian society does not see a place for itself in the ruling political institutions. Therefore, they had the right not to participate in the elections. The government should know that, if this procedure continues, this part of society will get bigger because even some of those who voted agree with this group.\"\n\nSix candidates, including five Conservatives, two of whom dropped out on the eve of the poll, were approved as qualified to stand by the Guardian Council, an unelected constitutional watchdog whose members are directly and indirectly appointed by supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\nThe decision to allow a reformist to stand was seen as a concession by the regime, which needed a more competitive election to try to lure voters to the polls.\n\nIran needs leaders with legitimacy as it supports resistance movements across the Middle East, confronts unelected Gulf monarchies and challenges the west over the purpose and scale of its currently expanding nuclear programme.\n\nOn Friday, the UN nuclear watchdog reported Tehran had installed four of eight new centrifuges at its Fordow facilities, speeding its uranium enrichment facilities.\n\nThe reformist movement that stretches back many decades inside Iran was divided over whether to participate, with many leading figures including political prisoners, such as the Nobel prize winner Narges Mohammadi, calling for a boycott.\n\nOther jailed thinkers on the left such as Majid Tavakoli urged voters from behind bars not to vote.\n\nJudging by the makeup of the sometimes large crowds at Pezeshkian's rallies, the reformists seem to have failed to persuade the younger generation demanding greater cultural freedom that their movement, or the route of the ballot box, offers real change. Some describe Gen Z Iran as depoliticised, and others simply conscious that elected politicians in Iran do not have controls over the levers of power that remain with the supreme leader, and the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.\n\nPezeshkian has used video town hall meetings to engage with students and promised no crackdown on those that refuse to wear the hijab. But at the heart of his campaign has been a call that the country's economic travails will not end unless it engages with western economies, including through renegotiating the Iranian nuclear deal. Actively supported by the former foreign minister Javad Zarif, he has accused hardliners of taking Iran down an ideological, cultural and economic cul-de-sac.\n\nThe big question now will be whether those around the supreme leader will hold an honest discussion about the turnout and self-evident alienation of Iranians.\n\nOne Tehran citizen, Kianoosh Sanjari, struck by the contrast between the official TV reports of excitement at the polls and what he had seen on the streets of the capital, travelled to 14 polling booths, and did not find more than five people queueing to vote. He said he then went to Laleh (Tulip) Park, one of his favourite haunts in Tehran, and found old men playing chess under a gazebo, crowds of youngsters playing badminton football and volleyball, and children practising slacklining.\n\n\"I don't know about the situation in other cities, but I can definitely say that the absolute majority of people in Tehran ignored the presidential appointments of the Islamic Republic of Iran and did not participate in them.\"\n\nHe added: \"All the domestic media of Iran served to heat up the oven of this election. Both sides were given a chance to speak their hearts out (and not to someone like me). Both factions sent text messages to the people. They conveyed their message to the people in all social networks.\n\n\"Call it discouragement, despair, indifference or collective consciousness.\"", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-401805511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-26", "time": "05:31:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-26T05:31:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-26T05:20:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/iran-picks-president-turbulent-time-052016156.html", "title": "Iran picks new president at turbulent time", "body": "Iranians vote on Friday to elect a new president from six candidates, including a lone reformist who hopes he can challenge the dominance of conservatives in the Islamic republic.\n\nA presidential election had not been due until 2025, but was brought forward after ultraconservative Ebrahim Raisi died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe snap poll comes at a challenging time as Iran grapples with the economic impact of international sanctions amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war between Israel and Tehran's ally Hamas.\n\nIn April Iran fired more than 300 missiles and drones at Israel after an air strike in Damascus blamed on Israel killed seven Revolutionary Guards.\n\nIsrael carried out a reported retaliatory strike near Isfahan.\n\nPolling is also being held just five months before a presidential election in the United States, Iran's sworn enemy and Israel's staunch ally.\n\nLeading contenders for Iran's second highest-ranking office are conservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, and the sole reformist, Massoud Pezeshkian.\n\nThe others are conservative Tehran mayor Alireza Zakani, cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, and incumbent vice president Amirhossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi, the ultraconservative head of the Martyrs' Foundation.\n\nThe six have staged largely low-key campaigns, which included televised debates where they vowed to tackle economic challenges and offered varied views on Iran's relations with the West.\n\nAli Vaez of the International Crisis Group says the new president will also have to tackle the challenge of the deepening \"fissure between the state and society\".\n\n\"Nobody has presented a concrete plan of how they are going to deal with a lot of these issues,\" he said.\n\n- 'No way I'm voting' -\n\nSupreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who wields the ultimate authority in Iran, urged \"high participation\" on Friday.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, voters shunned the polls after many reformists and moderates were disqualified.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent -- the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nPeople appear divided over whether voting will mean any key concerns being addressed.\n\nThese include the mounting effects of soaring inflation and the decline of the rial against the dollar.\n\n\"There's no way I'm voting,\" said Neda, an engineer who gave only her first name, in northern Tehran.\n\n\"No matter who takes the post, none of them is sympathetic with the nation. My vote won't affect anything,\" she told AFP.\n\nIn contrast, 60-year-old housewife Jaleh said she was rooting for reformist Pezeshkian, who comes \"from the people\" and could address unemployment and poverty.\n\nReformist figures including former president Mohammad Khatami and ex-foreign minister Mohammad Javad Zarif have endorsed Pezeshkian.\n\nHowever, some Iranians view the 69-year-old reformist as lacking government experience -- he only served as health minister about 20 years ago.\n\nOf the main contenders, Ghalibaf is a veteran politician and former member of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, ideological defenders of the republic after the 1979 revolution.\n\n- Dress code concerns -\n\nJalili, an ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator known for his inflexible stance towards the West, seems to be attracting hardline support.\n\nAlireza Valadkhani, a 35-year-old tax consultant, told AFP he will vote for Ghalibaf as he \"is the only one who can help Iran in its current situation\".\n\nOne concern among voters is whether a new president will mean a potential change to the contentious hijab law for women, particularly since the mass protests triggered by the 2022 death in custody of Mahsa Amini.\n\nAmini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurd, was detained for allegedly breaching Iran's dress code which makes women cover their heads and necks and wear modest clothing in public.\n\nSince the protests, women have increasingly flouted the code. But police have toughened controls in recent months on those who ignore the rules.\n\nMost of the candidates have been cautious in the televised debates, saying they generally opposed the use of violence against those who do not wear the mandatory headscarf.\n\n\"For 40 years, we have sought to fix the hijab, but we made the situation worse,\" Pezeshkian said in campaigning.\n\nFor many women, the idea of a change to the hijab laws seems far-fetched.\n\n\"It is hard for the candidates to fulfil their promises\" on this, said 31-year-old Maryam, who also gave only her first name.\n\nNeda said: \"The hijab law will never be lifted since this is the Islamic republic.\n\n\"I don't think any president would be willing to change this law.\"", "source": {"uri": Iran Presidential Race", "body": "TEMPO.CO, Dubai - A low-key moderate and a protege of Iran's supreme leader are neck-and-neck in the vote count in snap presidential elections marked by voter apathy over economic hardships and social restrictions.\n\nMore than 14 million votes have been counted so far from Friday's vote, June 28, of which the sole moderate candidate Massoud Pezeshkian had won over 5.9 million votes and his hardline challenger former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili over 5.5 million, provisional results by the interior ministry showed.\n\nSome insiders said the turnout was around 40%, lower than expected by Iran's clerical rulers, while witnesses told Reuters that polling stations in Tehran and some other cities were not crowded.\n\nIran's Tasnim news agency said a run-off election was \"very likely\" to pick the next president following the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nIf no candidate wins at least 50% plus one vote from all ballots cast, including blank votes, a run-off between the top two candidates is held on the first Friday after the result is declared.\n\nThe election coincides with escalating regional tension due to the war between Israel and Iranian allies Hamas in Gaza and Hezbollah in Lebanon, as well as increased Western pressure on Iran over its fast-advancing nuclear program.\n\nWhile the election is unlikely to bring a major shift in the Islamic Republic's policies, its outcome could influence the succession to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's 85-year-old supreme leader, in power since 1989.\n\nThe clerical establishment sought a high turnout to offset a legitimacy crisis fuelled by public discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom.\n\nThe next president is not expected to usher in any major policy shift on Iran's nuclear program or support for militia groups across the Middle East, since Khamenei calls all the shots on top state matters.\n\nHowever, the president runs the government day-to-day and can influence the tone of Iran's foreign and domestic policy.\n\nPezeshkian's views offer a contrast to those of Jalili, advocating detente with the West, economic reform, social liberalization, and political pluralism.\n\nA staunch anti-Westerner, Jalili's win would signal the possibility of an even more antagonistic turn in the Islamic Republic's With million of votes counted so far in Iran's snap presidential election, two candidates have emerged neck and neck - the sole moderate candidate, and a hardline conservative.\n\nElectoral officials opened ballot boxes early Saturday, after polling ended midnight.\n\nPreliminary results show moderate candidate Massoud Pezeshkian and his hardline challenger, former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili in the lead.\n\nPezeshkian, faithful to Iran's theocratic rule, has publicly criticized authorities over the death of Mahsa Amini.\n\nShe's an Iranian Kurdish woman who died in custody for allegedly violating Islamic dress code, and her death sparked mass unrest in Iran in 2022.\n\nJalili is a protege of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's 85-year-old supreme leader.\n\nA staunch anti-Westerner, analysts say him winning could signal an even more antagonistic turn in the Islamic Republic's foreign and domestic policy.\n\nThe election was sparked after the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nIt comes as tensions spike in the Middle East due to the war in Gaza, and Iranians face a struggling economy and U.S. sanctions.\n\nThe end result of the vote is unlikely to alter Iran's backing for militant groups and its relations with the West.\n\nBut it could alter domestic policies, and may shape succession to Khamenei, who's been in power since 1989.\n\nPublic discontent, "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://leadership.ng/iran-holds-presidential-elections-amid-challenges/", "title": "Iran Holds Presidential Elections Amid Challenges", "body": "Iranians will file out to cast their votes on Friday, June 28 to elect a new president from a pool of six candidates, which included a single reformist aiming to confront the influence of conservatives in the Islamic republic.\n\nA presidential election in Iran had not been due until 2025 but was brought forward after President Ebrahim Raisi died in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nThe snap poll comes at a challenging time as Iran grapples with the economic impact of international sanctions amid heightened regional tensions over the Gaza war between Israel and Tehran's ally Hamas.\n\nThe election is also being held just five months before a presidential election in the United States, Iran's sworn enemy and Israel's staunch ally.\n\nLeading contenders for Iran's second highest-ranking office are conservative parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf, ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, and the sole reformist, Massoud Pezeshkian.\n\nThe others are conservative Tehran mayor Alireza Zakani, cleric Mostafa Pourmohammadi, and incumbent vice president Amirhossein Ghazizadeh-Hashemi, the ultraconservative head of the Martyrs' Foundation.\n\nThe six have staged largely low-key campaigns, which included televised debates where they vowed to tackle economic challenges and offered varied views on Iran's relations with the West.\n\nAli Vaez of the International Crisis Group says the new president will also have to tackle the challenge of the deepening \"fissure between the state and society\".\n\n\"Nobody has presented a concrete plan of how they are going to deal with a lot of these issues,\" he said.\n\nSupreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who wields the ultimate authority in Iran has called for high participation on Friday.\n\nIn the 2021 election that brought Raisi to power, voters shunned the polls after many reformists and moderates were disqualified.\n\nThe turnout then was just under 49 percent, the lowest in any presidential election in Iran.\n\nPeople appear divided over whether voting will mean any key concerns on issues being addressed.\n\nThese include the mounting effects of soaring inflation and the decline of the rial against the dollar.\n\nNeda, an engineer who gave only her first name, in northern Tehran, said \"There's no way I'm voting.\n\n\"No matter who takes the post, none of them is sympathetic with the nation. My vote won't affect anything,\" she told AFP.\n\nIn contrast, 60-year-old housewife Jaleh said she was rooting for reformist Pezeshkian, who comes \"from the people\" and could address unemployment {"uri": "8201144488", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "06:50:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T06:50:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T06:49:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/middle-east/article/3268565/iran-presidential-election-reformist-pezeshkian-hardliner-jalili-lead-tight-race", "title": "Reformist, hardliner lead in tight Iran presidential race", "body": "The vote to pick the next president following the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash is likely heading to a run-off\n\nA low-key moderate and a prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Iran\u2019s supreme leader are neck-and-neck in the vote count in snap presidential elections marked by voter apathy over economic hardships and social restrictions.\n\nMore than 14 million votes have been counted so far from Friday\u2019s vote, of which the sole moderate candidate Massoud Pezeshkian had won over 5.9 million votes and his hardline challenger former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili over 5.5 million, provisional results by the interior ministry showed.\n\nSome insiders said the turnout was around 40 per cent, lower than expected by Iran\u2019s clerical rulers, while witnesses said that polling stations in Tehran and some other cities were not crowded.\n\nIran\u2019s Tasnim news agency said a run-off election was \u201cvery likely\u201d to pick the next president following the death of Ebrahim Raisi in a helicopter crash last month.\n\nIf no candidate wins at least 50 per cent plus one vote from all ballots cast, including blank votes, a run-off between the top two candidates is held on the first Friday after the result is declared.\n\nThe election coincides with escalating regional tension due to the war between Israel and Iranian allies Hamas in Gaza and Hezbollah in Lebanon, as well as increased Western pressure on Iran over its fast-advancing nuclear programme.\n\nWhile the election is unlikely to bring a major shift in the Islamic republic\u2019s policies, its outcome could influence the succession to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran\u2019s 85-year-old supreme leader, in power since 1989.\n\nThe clerical establishment sought a high turnout to offset a legitimacy crisis fuelled by public discontent over economic hardship and curbs on political and social freedom.\n\nThe next president is not expected to usher in any major policy shift on Iran\u2019s nuclear programme or support for militia groups across the Middle East, since Khamenei calls all the shots on top state matters.\n\nHowever, the president runs the government day-to-day and can influence the tone of Iran\u2019s foreign and domestic policy.\n\nPezeshkian\u2019s views offer a contrast to those of Jalili, advocating detente with the West, economic reform, social liberalisation and political pluralism.\n\nA staunch anti-Westerner, Jalili\u2019s win would signal the possibility of an even more antagonistic turn in the Islamic republic\u2019s foreign and domestic policy, analysts said.\n\nThe election was a contest among a tightly controlled group of three hardline candidates and one low profile moderate loyal to the supreme leader. A hardline watchdog body approved only six from an initial pool of 80 and two hardline candidates subsequently dropped out.\n\n\u201cBased on unconfirmed reports, the election is very likely heading to a second round \u2026 Jalili and Pezeshkian will compete in a run-off election,\u201d Tasnim reported.\n\nCritics of the clerical establishment say that low turnouts in recent years show the system\u2019s legitimacy has eroded. Turnout was 48 per cent in the 2021 presidential election and a record low of 41 per cent of people voted in a parliamentary election in March.\n\nAll candidates have vowed to revive the flagging economy, beset by mismanagement, state corruption and sanctions reimposed since 2018, after the US ditched Tehran\u2019s nuclear pact.\n\n\u201cI think Jalili is the only candidate who raised the issue of justice, fighting corruption and giving value to the poor. \u2026 Most importantly, he does not link Iran\u2019s foreign policy to the nuclear deal,\u201d said Farzan, a 45-year-old artist in the city of Karaj.\n\nPezeshkian, faithful to Iran\u2019s theocratic rule, is backed by the reformist faction that has largely been sidelined in Iran in recent years.\n\n\u201cWe will respect the hijab law, but there should never be any intrusive or inhumane behaviour toward women,\u201d Pezeshkian said after casting his vote.\n\nHe was referring to the death of Mahsa Amini, a young Kurdish woman, in 2022 while in morality police custody for allegedly violating the mandatory Islamic dress code.\n\nThe unrest sparked by Amini\u2019s death spiralled into the biggest show of opposition to Iran\u2019s clerical rulers in years.\n\nPezeshkian attempted to revive the enthusiasm of reform-minded voters who have largely stayed away from the polls for the last four years as a mostly youthful population chafes at political and social curbs. He could also benefit from his rivals\u2019 failure to consolidate the hardline vote.\n\nIn the past few weeks, Iranians have made wide use of the hashtag #ElectionCircus on X, with some activists at home and abroad calling for a boycott, saying a high turnout would only serve to legitimise the Islamic republic.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning 1979 revolution.\n\nIran's Supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, had called for a high turnout after casting his vote on Friday.\n\nIran will hold a run-off presidential election on July 5 after neither of the top candidates secured more than 50% of votes in Friday's polls, the interior ministry said on Saturday.\n\nThe vote to replace Ebrahim Raisi after his death in a helicopter crash came down to a tight race between the sole moderate in a field of four candidates and the supreme leader's hardline protege.\n\nWith more than 24 million votes counted moderate lawmaker Massoud Pezeshkian led with over 10 million votes ahead of hardline diplomat Saeed Jalili with over 9.4 million votes, according to provisional results released by the ministry.\n\nPower in Iran ultimately lies with
